Ottawa, January 9th, 1928.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 29th ultimo regarding the insurance on the new school in course of construction at Caughnawaga, I beg to inform you that the insurance should be extended to such a time as the building is fully completed by the contractor, the premium, of course, to be paid by him. The insurance should then be dropped as the Department does not carry risks on properties the cost of which has been paid from monies voted by Parliament. Insurance is only placed upon buildings the cost of which is paid from Band funds.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Examiner,
The Continental Insurance Company,
17 St. John Street,
Montreal, Que.
While making an inspection of the Central School last week at Caughnawaga, I noticed that the contractors were about to start the laying of the sewer pipe on a distance of over 500 feet. After consulting with the Indian Agent it was considered advisable to authorize someone to supervise at least the jointing and the filling over this drain pipe. I have therefore taken it upon myself to request Mr. Robert, one of the caretakers of the Government schools to attend to this work, with the understanding that he will be paid reasonable wages for this extra work. I have given Mr. Robert the necessary instructions to enable him to attend to this work which should be completed before the end of this month.

Owing to the absence of earth along the course of the above mentioned sewer line, I have also arranged for the purchase of fifty dollars worth of manure to cover the clay pipe in order to prevent it from damage by the pressure of loose stones, etc., in the filling of the trench. This condition of the soil could not, of course, be foreseen in the preparation of the specifications and will be at the charge of the Department.

While at the building my attention was brought to the difficulty of securing the services of a reliable workman to come to Caughnawaga at the present time, when transportation conditions are very inconvenient and undertake the construction of the terrazzo flooring in the toilet rooms in the basement. It was suggested for this reason that they be replaced by floors of red vitrified quarry tiles, laid with good coloured cement joints, similar to those manufactured by the Ontario Provincial Government. The contractors have a certain amount of these on hand, and are willing to supply the balance without extra charge. As this latter type of flooring is much more sanitary than that made of terrazzo, I beg to recommend that this change be authorized. I would ask your approval of the above mentioned arrangements.

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.
Sir,

I beg to inform you that it is necessary that the fire insurance policy on the new Central School, which expired on the 9th instant, be immediately renewed and forwarded to the Department with the least possible delay and would suggest that this new policy be increased to $30,000 to enable the Department to issue another progress certificate before its expiration.

With reference to your request for the substitution of red vitrified quarry tile flooring for the terrazzo as specified, for the lavatories in the basement of the school, I beg to say that this change will be permitted on condition that these tiles be equal in quality to those manufactured by the Ontario Provincial Government, also that these tile floors be laid in an entirely satisfactory manner with neat and even coloured joints and without any additional charge to the Department whatsoever.

The Department is advised that there is some exterior woodwork which has not yet received its priming coat of oil paint, and also that the heating of the building is far from being satisfactory. I have to request, therefore, that you arrange for the painting of this woodwork as early as possible, and that you take the necessary steps to fully protect the interior work by an adequate supply of heat until the completion and acceptance of the building as required by your specifications.

Messrs. MacKenzie & Genest,
Contractors,
Caughnawaga,
Que.

With reference to the filling over the drain pipe of the sewerage system for this school, I beg to say that the Department has authorized the purchase of a quantity of manure to be delivered along the trench for the covering of the pipes before the stone filling is started, with the understanding that the cost of the quantity required will not exceed fifty dollars. It is desired that all care possible be taken in the filling of the trench in order that the drain pipe be not disturbed or damaged when the ground settles next spring.

Ottawa, January 13, 1928.

Sir:

I have acknowledged receipt of the voucher which you forwarded to the amount of $154.76 covering general disbursements in connection with the supervising of the R.C. Indian day schools on the Oughmawag Reserve and for disbursements for driver and messenger boy.

In connection with these accounts, it is noted that a duplicate charge is made for visits to St. Isidore Road School. Five visits were made during the period from September 19th to the end of December. A charge of $1.50 is made for the driver and also $1.50 in the account for disbursements made by Rev. Sister Mary Rose Alma. Please explain why this duplicate charge is made for these visits.

There is also an amount of $65 charged for the transportation of the teachers to the schools on stormy days and during the month of December. While the Department would be prepared to allow a reasonable amount for the transportation of the teachers on stormy days, it is considered that transportation should not be provided at any other time. Please take this matter up with the Rev. Sister Superior and have her state the number of times the teachers were given transportation on stormy days during the period covered by this account, and also to whom the same was paid and whether receipts are obtained. We note that this item is gradually increasing, and you should inform the Rev. Sister that it is only on stormy days or during extremely wet weather that we could pay for the cost of transporting the Sisters to the schools.

Your early reply giving full particulars as requested above is desired before payment of the account which you submit can be made.

I beg to inform you that we are authorizing the Rev. Sister Superior to incur an expenditure not exceeding $65 in the purchase of sewing material. The account covering the cost will be handed to you, which you should certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

L. Latourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant,
P. Q.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Ottawa, January 13, 1928.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, requesting that the usual grant of $65 be allowed to purchase sewing material for the R.C. Indian day schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding the above amount in the purchase of materials required for the teaching of sewing.

Please obtain an itemized account, in duplicate, which you should hand to Mr. Agent Letourneau, who has been informed of the authority granted for this expenditure. He will certify the account and send it to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sister Mary Rose Alma,
Supervising Principal,
R.C. Indian Day Schools,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

Jan. 18, 1928.

Sir,

Replying to your inquiry made to Mr. Chase of this Department, concerning the colour of the paint for the woodwork at the Central School at Caughnawaga, I beg to say that the staining of the B.C. fir should be light or golden oak. The metal ceilings should be painted light gray. The outside woodwork and metal work, with the exception of the window sashes, should be painted a light buff. Samples of golden oak, light gray and buff are enclosed herewith and the colours used should be similar to samples.

Other woodwork, whether outside or inside the building, should be finished in accordance with the colour chosen by the Superior of the School.

You are authorized to change the location of some doors on the ground floor of the school building at a cost not exceeding £69.00.

The Department will advise you further in the course of a day or so concerning the installation of a combined wood and metal stairs from the ground floor leading to the theatre on the first floor.

Kindly acknowledge receipt of this letter and that sent you on the 11th instant, and advise me why the Insurance Policy issued is not for $30,000 as requested.

Your obedient servant,

Messrs. MacKenzie & Genest,
Contractors,
Caughnawaga, Que.

A. P. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Jan. 19, 1928.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that you may proceed at once with the construction of a wooden stairs, landing, etc., at the North-east end of the corridor on the ground floor leading to the rear of the Theatre on the first floor of the new Central School at Caughnawaga, in accordance with the details mentioned and agreed upon with the Departmental Engineer when last making an inspection of the above mentioned building and subject to his acceptance.

It should be understood that this work will be carried out in the same manner and constructed of similar material as the other stairs in this building, at a cost not to exceed $350.00, this price to include any repairs which might be found to be necessary and resulting from this additional work.

The cast iron stairs will be purchased direct by the Department and shipped to you as soon as I am advised of the exact height between the landing and the Theatre floor. The cost of the installation of this metal stairs is included in the extra payment of $350.00 above mentioned.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of January 11th we like to inform you that the insurance on building was removed in Jan 9th and returned to the Department before we received your letter and in the next renewal we will increase to the amount as call for as we did not get notice in time.

In regard to outside painting we were notified by the Inspector Mr Letourneau not to do any outside painting until such time as weather permits same, otherwise this work could have been completed sometime ago, at present the weather is too cold to do so.

In regard as to the manner for covering pipes in trenches we have ordered same and we are using it as we proceed with refilling and all possible care has been taking to protect the pipes. We remain

Yours Truly,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant. In this connection I wish to refer to my letter of November 25th, 1928, in which I have already explained what the Department claim to be a duplicate charge for visits to St-Isidore Road School. Sister Superior is allowed $1.50 for her visit to that school which is three miles one way, making it a six miles drive with horse and carriage in very bad country roads. No driver will go there with a wait of one hour or more for less than $1.50.

When Reverend Sister Superior visited the Departmental Offices last August, she made known to the Superintendent of Indian Education the request of the Reverend Mother General of her Order to have Sisters driven to the Girls' School because of the distance from the Residence. He, therefore, agreed to have the Department pay $35.00 a month for December, January, February and March if necessary. One excellent teacher who taught at the Girls' School last year caught a bad cold that regenerated into tuberculosis. She has been confined in the T.B. Department at the Sisters Infirmary since last August with no prospect of curing.

No woman can plough through the snow, kneedeep any great distance, with freezing temperature and in all sorts of wintry stormy days and that four times a day without feeling the effects sooner or later.

All the Reverend Sisters under the School Board of Montreal who teach even a short distance from the Convent

4. 13. The company is not liable for any loss following, that is to say:

Sir,

I acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th inst., concerning the building of the central school at Longuevaux.

In reply, I must inform you that at the time of my last visit of inspection at that school, I found that on account of the total absence of heat in the interior, which was by that fact causing much dampness, the carpentry work had to be temporarily discontinued; the work in connection with the heating system was kept up. One of the contractors told me that it was impossible for them to furnish heat as required inside the building before the installation of an electric pump was done.

Yesterday, Mr. Binette, of Quebec, telephoned me to say that he had received instructions from the Department to have an electric pump installed immediately, but that on account of the changes in the specifications which he had submitted to the Department with his price of $150.00, he had said he received instructions to change the specifications so as to put a 3" pipe instead of one of 1½" to a depth of 40 feet in the artesian well and that he was furthermore instructed to connect the electric current from the transformer to the building. On account of this change in the specifications he had submitted, Mr. Binette then informed me that he could not do this work for less than $150.00 instead of $150.00 as previously tendered.

As this work was most urgent, I
thoughts I could take upon myself to authorize Mr. Bissette to proceed without delay with the work at the price of $150.00.

The work to the sewer system is progressing in a satisfactory manner; I believe the laying of the pipe and the connection done during the course of a week.

Yours truly,

Madam:

March 13, 1926.

Memorandum

While at Caughnawaga last month I visited the boys' school and noticed that the shallow well which was supplying water to this building had dried up. As it is important that a reliable supply of water be provided for a school of this kind, I would recommend that a deep artesian well be bored as early as funds are available, and that the work be entrusted to Mr. Fortin of Montreal who has done similar boring at the Caughnawaga Hospital and the new School in a thoroughly satisfactory manner. I estimate that the work would cost about $300.

Funds can be important.

Well you please give the instructions.

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.

I beg to confirm the instructions given you by the Departmental Engineer when last making an inspection of the Central School on the 27th instant, concerning the following items of work:

1. The concrete floor in the boiler and fuel room should be graded in such a manner as to allow the water to drain itself into the new gulley.

2. Means should be taken when cleaning the tile floors in the toilets to stain the cement joints, which have been left in their natural colour, as was understood in my letter of the 11th of January, authorizing the substitution of red quarry tiles for terrazzo.

3. The corner posts of the C. C. compartments from the bottom railing should be supported with metal legs formed of nickel plated steel pipe with suitable flange at top and bottom anchored to the tile floor with anchor bolts, etc. The top flanges of the posts should be shaped to have same width as that of the post itself. I understand that the above mentioned fittings can be obtained from dealers in plumbing fixtures, as they are frequently used for partitions made of marble.

4. The doors should be adjusted with standard triplex spring single action hinges of the size required for this type of door, and illustrated in Belleville Hardware Cat. No 4, page 253. They should be provided with lavatory door pull and latch, and door pull on the outside as shown on pages 262 and 265 of the above mentioned catalogue, or approved equal.

April 27, 1926.

Sir,

Replying to your request made personally to the Departmental Engineer that the Insurance Policy on the Central School building be discontinued as soon as the building is occupied, I regret to say that the Department is unable to authorize this course, as the specifications require that the building be kept insured until it has been accepted and entirely completed. I understand that the interior will be ready for occupation the first week of May, but that it will take several weeks more before the exterior is completed, owing to the unfavourable weather conditions, and the amount of repairs which will have to be made to the jointing, the brick veneering and the cement work, which as you know is entirely unsatisfactory. I would ask you, therefore, to furnish me with a renewal receipt of the Fire Insurance Policy before the date of its expiration.

With reference to the spring hinged adjusted on the lavatory doors, I beg to say that these will not be accepted under any consideration, as they would not stand the frequent use of the doors. Each of the lavatory doors should be adjusted with two 5" single action, triplex spring hinges as required in the specifications.

The Department is advised by the firm of Thomas Lawson that the balance of the guard railing for the spiral stairs above the Theatre floor will be shipped within the course of a few days, and it is understood with this firm that they will be responsible for the payment of any additional work which might have been required for the installation of these stairs, due to defective construction by them. You should therefore communicate with this company if you have any claim for extra payment in this connection.

CRANE Automatic WATER SYSTEMS

Running water—the burden bearer

Bringer of health and comfort, saver of labor, frequently an increaser of profits, running water is perhaps as important a contribution to modern life as mechanical ingenuity has made.

In the kitchen, it renders irksome tasks easier. In the laundry, it lightens drudgery. In the bathroom, it lends vigor for the day's duties or soothes muscles weary from work. Piped to barn lots, it saves a vast amount of pumping and carrying while it promotes the productivity of stock and poultry. In the garden, it ends the threat of drought.

Public health officers, studying vital statistics, have found that running water in homes saves thousands of babies' lives, and promotes adult health as well.

Serving the well being of the entire family, making life easier for man, woman, and beast, the great benefit of running water is that it is not an expense but almost invariably a profitable investment.

Dominion and provincial agricultural leaders, and agricultural colleges, after a study of the effect of running water on farm profits, are sending out bulletins in which a characteristic statement is: "No equipment for farm homes is needed more than water under pressure. Plan a complete plumbing system. If necessary, have it installed in units as circumstances permit."

But most people, and especially most women, know without being told how much they need running water. For farm families and for dwellers in small towns and suburbs away from city water mains, the problem has been to find a way to get it without prohibitive trouble and expense. Now, that way has been found.

Efficient ~ economical ~ enduring

CRANE Automatic WATER SYSTEMS

Nine superior features of Crane Deep Well Systems

Where water cannot be reached at a vertical depth of 22 feet, a deep well system becomes necessary. Covering every condition under which a deep well system must operate, no more efficient and economical systems are manufactured than Crane. Some superior features of Crane systems are:

1. Backed by the 72-year Crane reputation for reliability.
2. Every part easily accessible for adjustment and repairs.
3. Parts oversize for greater strength.
4. Bearings machined to .0005 of an inch.
5. Well-head entirely housed to keep out dust and all foreign substances.
6. Positive oiling system which keeps every bearing flooded and requires the minimum of attention.
7. Repulsion-induction type motor for alternating current. D. C. motor furnished if required.
8. All electric systems entirely automatic, starting and stopping with pressure variations.
9. Supplied also for gasoline power, with a Fuller and Johnson air-cooled engine mounted with the head.
The Crane Deep Well System No. 850

A striking value

The new Crane No. 850 Deep Well System effectively meets the need for a reasonably priced, well-made system which will pump water from any depth. With such a system on the market, no one is justified in doing without the health-giving, comfort-giving, labor-saving qualities of running water.

This new system is made in capacities to pump 125 to 510 gallons an hour from depths down to 250 feet. Built of the finest materials, machined to a precision not found in ordinary pumps, this system is constructed in every detail for enduring untroubled operation.

It shares with other Crane systems the advantages of accessibility, simplicity, and easy repair which are so valuable in assuring buyer-satisfaction.

It is self-oiling. Most heads of this type depend on the dip of the cross-head and crank pin for oiling of these parts. In the Crane No. 850, this practice has been improved by providing a positive overhead oiling system. The oil is collected in a reservoir between the pinions at the high point and carried by gravity to every bearing and pin, including the cross-head and guide rod. This construction means longer life for every part.

An important feature is the ease with which the sucker rods and plunger can be removed when connected to an open type working barrel or cylinder. The head need never be removed from the foundation to accomplish this occasional servicing. Since the water chamber and head proper remain intact in this operation there is no possibility of the two parts ever getting out of alignment when removing the rods and plungers. It is entirely enclosed as a protection against dirt and foreign substances.

It will not pound. The pump, of the walking beam type, has a sliding cross-head which moves the rod down at greater speed than up, cushioning the upstroke.

The system can be operated with either electric or gas engine power. With electric motor, two styles of drive are offered; the standard, with belt and idler, and a silent chain drive with guard. The chain drive, supplied at slight extra cost, is recommended for its long, trouble-free service and greater efficiency. For those who have their own gas engine power and belt drive, the pump is available with tight pulley only; while for line shaft drive it can be furnished with tight and loose pulley at a small extra charge.

Length of stroke is 6 inches and is not adjustable. Pulley size, when furnished, is 16 inches by 2¼ inches. Recommended speed—40 to 45 strokes a minute. Water chamber—bolted to head, has packing tube and air pump.

Regularly tapped to receive a maximum of 3½ inch drop pipe, and can be bushed down to smaller sizes.

A frost-proof attachment can be furnished when the head cannot be placed where it will be protected from frost.

CRANE Automatic WATER SYSTEMS

FLOAT SWITCH

This is an automatic control for open tank installations. It consists of a regular switch box with levers and cross bar, a brass rod with stop collars, and a spherical copper float. It can be adjusted to operate between any desired levels by moving the collars on the rod accordingly. The pressure of the rising water level raises the float against the top collar and breaks the contacts in the switch. When water is drained from the tank, the float lowers with the water level until it rests on the bottom collar, and the weight of the float then throws the switch into contact.

When ordering a float switch give inside height of tank so the brass rod can be cut to proper length.

May 16, 1928.

Sir,

I beg to confirm the instructions given you yesterday by the Departmental Engineer as to some of the work remaining to be done in connection with your contract for the erection of the new Central School at Caughnawaga, before final certificate is issued. These consist mainly of the following works:

Repairing of cement floor around the galley in the boiler room.
The adjustment of suitable lock to the door of the coal chute.
The painting of wooden plates underneath the electric fixtures, alarm bells, etc., also the steel boxes containing the electric panel boards; air valves on radiators in ventilation ducts, galvanized iron cornices, kalumine doors to match the adjoining woodwork; also the painting of all galvanized iron water supply pipes, an additional coat of white enamel to be put on the base of drinking fountains, and painting of all plastered walls in small alcove where automatic tank for the heating system is located, on first floor.
The installing of door bell in class rooms.
The repairing of soot door in chimney.
Leveling of excavated earth around building as directed.
The adjustment of drips at base of steel triangle supports of fire escapes.
Readjustment of cylinder lock of pupils' entrance.
Installing of Liquid door checks.
The plastering of weather asphalt stripping around all windows and door openings.
Repairs to asbestos shingle roof.
Installing of round ventilation registers at ceiling in four of the class rooms.
Repairing of cast iron grates in one of the furnaces.
Completion of spiral stairs back of the theatre.
Cleaning of cupboards around assembly hall and removing of superfluous material inside and outside of building.

Messrs. MacKenzie & Genest,
Contractors,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Adjustment of slate blackboards.
Adjustment of wooden door sills so as to leave no air space between stone sills of entrances.
The levelling, polishing and finishing of the hardwood floor in the hall of the main entrance.

As you are aware the brick veneering cannot be accepted in its present condition, and as I understand that there are already a number of brick layers repairing this part of the work a further inspection of the building will be made before a final decision is given with regard to this part of the work.

A copy of this letter is being sent to both the Indian Agent and the Superior of the School, who should advise as soon as the above mentioned work has been satisfactorily completed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting, Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, June 20, 1928.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, giving a list of the equipment which you request be supplied for the use of the new Central and other Schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve, together with quotations which you received for the supplying of an electric range, and also quotations from the Clovis Electric Company for the supplying of school balls.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Education, is at present in the West and will not return to Ottawa until early in August, next. The question of ordering the supplies asked for in your letter, and also the bells, will receive consideration immediately upon his return. There will be ample time after that date to obtain the supplies considered necessary before the school re-opens after the summer holidays. You may inform the firms from whom you received quotations that the same will be given consideration after the return of the Superintendent of Indian Education.

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, June 26, 1928.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find letter from Mr. Theoret with sketch stating price for the cupboards and counter needed for the Domestic Science room. After many inquiries I find it much more economical to have the wall cupboards built by a lumber company and installed by a carpenter. It takes at least three weeks to get an order filled at the mill and ten days to have the work completed. Then comes the buying of dishes, kitchen utensils and all that is necessary to carry on that activity.

Altho I understand it is preferable to wait for Mr. Ferrier's return before any decision can be given regarding the purchases required for the next scholastic year, could there not be an exception made in a case such as the one mentioned above.

Assuredly it will be utterly impossible to open that class if the cupboards, counter and electric installation are not attended to before August. The Indians are looking forward to the opening of the Domestic Science class and a disappointment of that kind will mean trouble to me.

Hoping you will understand my situation, I am, dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Ottawa, June 28, 1928.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, enclosing the quotation which you received for the building of the cupboards and counter needed for the domestic science room in the new Central School on the Caughnawaga Reserve. As it will take time to have this work carried out and in order to prevent delay, the Department will approve of the acceptance of the quotation of J. Theoret, general contractor, of Lachine, to build and install the cupboards and counter. It is noted that his quotation for the building of the cupboards, as per the sketch which you enclosed, is $150, and for the building of the counter, as per sketch enclosed, $130. You may therefore arrange with him to undertake this work and have same completed to your satisfaction at as early a date as possible. The Department is leaving this matter in your hands, as it is assured you will see that the work is satisfactorily performed. When the cupboards and counter have been installed, Mr. Theoret should submit his accounts in duplicate to Mr. Agent Letourneau, who is being informed of the authority granted you. Mr. Letourneau will certify the accounts and send them to the Department for payment.

Relative to any electrical installation that may be required in connection with the fitting up of this domestic science room, I shall be pleased if you will obtain prices and submit them to the Department, when consideration will be given to authorising having the work done. Quotations for this work could be secured at the time prices are being obtained for the wiring of the teacher's residence for an electric range.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Some years ago an agreement was entered into between the Missionary of Caughnawaga and the Department whereby water was to be furnished to the Girls' School from the water supply system in the Mission building, on condition that the Department would assume the cost of operation and maintenance of the water work system, which is located in the basement of the Mission building, the Missionary to look after the operating and care of the machinery. This agreement was for a period of 25 years. Owing to the freezing of the pipe in the basement of the Church the Girls' School was without water for several weeks in the past few years, and for this reason with the consent of the Missionary the agreement was cancelled, in accordance with letter of the 27th of March.

The Department will, therefore, not be responsible for the payment of any accounts in connection with the above mentioned system in future. My reason for certifying to the voucher hereunder, is due to the fact that the repairs were carried out prior to the cessation of the Agreement.

Translation:
I beg to ask you if the department would kindly authorize me to do some work in the old concert hall of the Kateri school, in the village of Caughnawaga. It would be necessary to build a Beaver-board partition to make an entrance hall at the end of which would be a cloakroom such as there is one at the Eastern school. I believe the cost of this work would not amount to much as we could use the Beaver-board which has been discarded from the principal entrance of the Kateri school. If the department wishes to authorize me to do so I will inquire into the approximate cost of the work.

Monsieur,

J'ai bien reçu votre lettre du 28 courant et en réponse de vous informer que les travaux de nettoyage de la brique à l'Ecole Senior sont terminés et paraissent acceptables. Il reste bien quelques taches de peinture dans le pignon est, mais je crois que cela n'a pas beaucoup d'importance. La brique reste aussi tachée un peu noirâtre en dessous des échelles de sauvatage, due probablement à la peinture de ces escaliers, mais cela est inévitable. En avant, chaque côté de l'entrée principale, l'eau qui descend de la couverture fait aussi deux coulisses de teinte quelque peu plus foncée. Est-ce que l'eau de la couverture qui suivra ainsi sur la brique durant les temps froids ne sera pas de nature à endommager les joints ? Est-ce qu'il serait nécessaire d'y mettre des dalles ? Les fondations ont aussi été teintées et ont une meilleure apparence.

Je crois que l'eau en face de l'hôpital est suffisamment basse pour y terminer les travaux. D'ailleurs elle ne viendra pas plus basse durant le cours de cette année.

Mlle. Dumont désire vous voir lorsque vous viendrez à Caughnawaga au sujet de ce projet d'installation d'outillage pour adoucir l'eau, etc., et ma Reyde, Soeur Supérieure de même.

Votre dévoue,

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Robert

While in Caughnawaga this week I made a final inspection of the Central School, and I beg to make the following suggestions in connection with this building.

The fencing should be erected as early as possible to prevent the cattle from roaming around the building, as the artificial stone has been considerably damaged by the cattle during the night, and the mound is unfit for the children to use as playground. Provision should also be made for the cleaning of the school grounds which is filled with large boulders, and for the filling of the holes where stone has been quarried. This work can be done economically by day labour, under the supervision of Mr. Robert, Caretaker of the School.

A slate or marble partition 24" x 3/4" x 4'6" is required to separate the two urinals in the boys' lavatory. This material can be purchased here in Ottawa, and shipped to the caretaker of the school, who is willing to install it in place.

One faucet is required in the recreation room to allow water to be taken with pails for the cleaning of the floors, etc. The faucets in the water basins are too low for this purpose. This work can be done by the plumber who will have charge of the installation of the hot water tank in the boiler room.

With reference to the furnishing and installing of hot water system for the domestic science classroom, I would suggest that the electrical work be entrusted to Mr. Needing of the Clovis Electric Co., who has already done work in this building, and that the plumbing work be given to Mr. Pilon, plumber, of Lachine, who has offered to carry out this work reasonably.

Sept. 7, 1926.

Sir,

I wish to inform you that an inspection was made last Wednesday by an officer of this Department of the brick and stone work at the Central School, Oungnawag, which was lately repaired by your firm, on behalf of the contractors, Messrs. MacKenzie and Gossel of Ottawa. The work was found satisfactory, with the exception of a portion of the brick veneer on the east side of the front elevation near the top where there are about 25 bricks which are still discoloured, and which should be removed to make a satisfactory job. The Sister Superior of the School has been requested to give you the necessary explanation as to the portion of the brick veneer which requires cleaning, and I would ask you to attend to this matter with the least possible delay, in order that the contractors might be authorised to pay your account for this work. I shall be grateful if you will advise the Department when the work is completed, and furnish me with accounts in duplicate approved by the Superior of the School.

Your obedient servant,

Lachine, Sep. 15th 1928

Dear Sir,

With reference to your favour of the 1st inst. concerning the installation of a telephone in the Senior School of Caughnawaga, I may state that this particular kind of service cannot be given at the present time because the proposed telephone line has not as yet been installed. But when it will be completed the tariff for each phone shall be $2.30 per month and in addition you share of the sum of $10.22, being the additional charged by the C.P.R. for each two telephone wires over the bridge between Highlands and Achonndack.

As you seemingly refer only to the school, where two phones will have to be erected, if the cost of installation exceeds $50.00 the difference over this amount will have to be paid by you in addition to the usual of charge of $2.30 for installation.

As the season is well advanced we would expect a reply as soon as possible if you wish the installation to be made this year.

Yours truly,

J. G. Gibbon

Oct. 16, 1928.

Memo: Dr. Scott.

Competitive prices have been obtained from the following firms for the furnishing of a pneumatic water supply system comprising a deep well pump with compressor attachment, electric motor, and a steel water pressure tank for the supplying of water to the girls' school at Gauginawage, where a number of plumbing and sanitary fixtures are already installed. The installation of this system became necessary on account of discontinuing taking water from the water system at the Mission building across the road, which did not give continuous service. The supply pipe connecting both systems was frozen most of the winter season, and on this account the Department was compelled to pay for the transportation of water. The prices received are as follows:

Crane Limited, Montreal, $294.50
Darling Bros., Montreal, $270.00
Canadian Fairbanks Morse, Montreal, $371.10 and Ottawa.

I beg to recommend that the order be placed with the firm quoting the lowest price, and that the installation be entrusted to the Clovis Electric Co., who have already done similar work in other schools on this Reserve at a reasonable charge. The Schools Branch have stated that funds are available to cover this work.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to improvements at the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School. On the 20th ultimo, Mr. Indian Agent Letourneau was authorized to arrange for the installation of a telephone in the Senior School. A claim was submitted to the Department through the office of the Indian Agent last summer, from an Indian woman by the name of Mrs. Cecilia Hanson, who resides on the Caughnawaga Malone Highway, Caughnawaga Reserve. She claimed an amount of $21.00 representing the cost of repairs required to her house, which she claimed had been damaged by blasting at the time of the construction of the sewer line for the Central School last winter. The trench, which was dug in solid rock, passes quite close to her house, but all possible precautions were taken by the contractors to prevent damage. I consider that it was probably on account of her house being very old that the blasting affected it, if such was the case. This matter was submitted to Indian Agent Letourneau who reported that the claim appeared to be fair and reasonable according to hearsay.

I since interviewed the contractors concerning this matter and they have convinced me that they cannot be held responsible in any way for damage done to property in the vicinity of the school, in view of the fact that they took every care possible when the work was being carried out. The request, for this reason, was left in abeyance, and no further communication has been received from that Indian woman.

The Department has just received a claim amounting to $15.00 from Mrs. J. Canadian, whose property is also located in the neighborhood of the School. It is curious to note that these claims were not sent in last winter at the time of the performance of the work which they claim was the cause of the damage. However, as I know that the work was carried out with as much care as possible, and that the contractors went to the expense of boarding up the windows, replacing broken glass, etc., I would suggest that these claims be not given any consideration.

The agreement referred to in Rev. Father Hauser's letter of the 19th instant between the Department and the Missionary of Caughnawaga was drawn up in September 1919, whereby the latter, in summary, agreed to allow the water pipe from the girls' school to be connected to the water supply system then in operation at the Mission building, on condition that the Department would assume the cost of supplying the gasoline for the operation of the system, would pay for the cost of a number of improvements to the system which were considered necessary at that time, and maintain the system in a good state of repair in the future. In return the Missionary was to take care of the whole installation and its proper operation, during a period of 25 years.

As it became obvious later that the upkeep and operation of the system entailed too large an expenditure on the part of the Department, it became advisable to provide an independent and more adequate water supply for this school. The Agent was, therefore, requested in February 1927 to obtain from the Missionary an annulment of this agreement, and this was confirmed in a communication from the Missionary on March 27th last, turned out hereunder together with the agreement. No accounts have since been submitted by the Missionary in connection with the upkeep or operation of the system, and the Department was under the impression that the necessary water for the school was being supplied from a shallow well pump.

The Department was advised on the 7th instant by the Principal of the School that this was not the case, and that the school had continued to obtain water from the old system at her request. She submitted to me in the presence of the Agent, when I was last in Caughnawaga, a number of accounts with a request that I arrange for a refund to the Missionary. I suggested that the Missionary's request be submitted direct to the Department, as I explained that I was under the impression that since the agreement was discontinued last spring the Department was under no obligation towards the maintenance or operation of this system. Furthermore I do not understand the accompanying accounts, and I would respectfully
suggest that the whole matter be referred to the Indian Agent, in order that the Department might be furnished with a report as to whether it would be justified in giving the Missionary's request any consideration.

I may add for your information that an artesian well has been sunk at this school, and an order for the necessary pumping equipment was given some time ago. It is expected that a reliable system will be in operation in the course of a few days.

Yesterday, while at my office at Caughnawaga I have received from Rev. Hauser an insulting letter, stating particularly among other false accusations that I intend to deprive his mission of the payment by the Department for the repairs, etc., of the water supply system from the Presbytery to the Kateri School.

May I ask you that in future I could be exempted of any further interviews with Rev. Hauser.

With Reverend Father Granger, I have examined these accounts and I believe that their payment should now be made by the Department. Voucher No. 1537 amounting $248.17 is enclosed herewith.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Harder,

As you are aware a large quantity of anthracite coal is purchased each year for the various government buildings on the Caughnawaga Reserve. The coal is ordered directly by the Department and is delivered to the buildings by the Indians without any checking of the weight or the amount delivered to each building. After giving this question serious consideration I am convinced that a large saving could be effected if the heating system were operated by employing either fuel oil or buckwheat coal using a forced draft system. Should you give this matter further consideration I will gladly furnish you with additional information as to the saving that can be made and the cost of each type of installation.

Ottawa, February 25, 1929.

Memorandum.

Dr. Scott,

While at the Central School lately I noticed that some reinforcing work was necessary to properly support the wooden beam over the arches in the ceiling of two alcoves in the Assembly Hall on the first floor of the Senior School.

It appears that the wooden posts supporting the beam have gradually settled, thus causing the plaster to crack in places. To remedy this condition, I would strongly urge that steel posts and extra beams be erected to strengthen this part of the building. This work could be economically carried out when general repairs are being performed at other schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve. I beg to recommend that the Agent be authorized at once to attend to this matter as early as convenience.

The material required will only consist of 4-5"x5" columns and two 12" beams with the necessary fastening rods.

Departmental Engineer.

Monsieur,

Pour faire suite à votre lettre du 13 courant relativement aux diverses réparations qui doivent être faites par la Compagnie Clovis Electric, Montréal, aux écoles ainsi qu'à la résidence à Caughnawaga, je crois devoir vous faire observer que des travaux supplémentaires sont nécessaires en plus de ceux déjà décrits dans ma liste que j'ai soumise au Département le 31 janvier dernier.

Les piliers sous les colonnes des entrées principales aux écoles Eastern et Kateri devraient être refaites avec de nouvelles bases en ciment placées à l'épreuve de la gelée; il devrait en être de même pour l'entrée du soubassement à l'école Eastern. Cette entrée se détériore à cause des premiers rangs de briques qui s'effritent sous l'action de gelé.

Le lambrisage actuel en V dans la cuisine de la résidence des Soeurs devrait, je crois, être remplacé par du B.C. fir sur lequel il devrait être donnée une couche de "filler" et vernis.

Je crois aussi devoir recommander que la peinture Sanitone soit employée sur l'enduit de la grande salle de concert à l'école Senior, parceque cette peinture est plus facile d'entretien que la peinture à l'eau.

Le système des cloches électriques qui est installé à l'extérieur des écoles Eastern et Kateri est en mauvais ordre, je recommande que ce système soit renouvelé.

In response to your letter of the 13th instant, concerning the different repairs to be done by the Oblate Electric Company, Montreal, to the schools and the residence at Baie-Comeau, I wish to bring to your attention that supplementary work will be necessary above that already described in my last report to the Dept. on the 30th January last.

The pillars under the columns at the principal entrance of the Eastern and Western schools should be rebuilt with new cement bases built close together. It should be the same for the entrance to the basement of the Eastern School. This entrance is deteriorating on account of the first rows of bricks which are breaking under the weight.

The Vaillant water closet in the kitchen of the latter residence should, I believe, be replaced by W.C. for on which a coat of "filler" and varnish could be applied. I also wish to recommend that stoneware hand basins be installed on the dressing of the large concert hall of the Senior school, as that kind of paint is easier to keep clean than water colours.

The electric bell system outside the Eastern and Western schools is in bad order; I recommend it be renewed. At the Protestant school quite important repairs are necessary. A new articulation well should be sunk. Water is lacking absolutely at this school, also for the W.C., which should be rebuilt outside.

The outside doors, windows and stairs should be repaired and painted.

Please instruct your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Monsieur,

Je dois vous informer que dans le cours de la semaine dernière, à Caughnawaga, j'ai rencontré le Reverend Père Hauser, s.j. Ptre Missionnaire, qui m'a demandé de soumettre au Departement la question d'un raccordement du système pour la fourniture de l'eau qui est présentement installé dans l'école Kateri, à celui du Presbytère, pour la raison que les Missionnaires ne peuvent se procurer autrement l'eau potable nécessaire à leur subsistance.

Un tuyau pour la conduite de l'eau existe déjà entre le Presbytère et l'école Kateri. Il suffirait de faire faire ce raccordement dans le soubassement de l'école.

Cependant, je ne suis pas prêt à en recommander dès maintenant l'exécution, pour la raison que des difficultés ont déjà surgies avec le Reverend Père Hauser au sujet de cette fourniture de l'eau qui était faite dans le temps par les Reverends Peres., en sens inverse.

Depuis que le Departement a fait faire une installation qui semble fonctionner admirablement bien, le Reverend Père Hauser aimerait sans doute maintenant tirer avantage de ce service pour la fourniture de l'eau pour le Presbytère. Sir,

I have to inform you that during the course of last week at Caughnawaga I met Rev. Father Hamer, a missionary who asked me to submit to the Department the question of connecting the water system at present installed at the school to that of the Presbytery, for the reason that the missionaries cannot get a supply of drinkable water otherwise.

A water pipe already exists between the new battery and the school. It would be sufficient to have it connected in the cellar of the school.

However, I am not inclined to recommend without the execution of this project, for the reason that difficulties arose in the past about this supply of water, which at that time was installed in the reverse way by the Rev. Fathers to the school.

Since the Department has had an installation made which works admirably well, Rev. F. Hamer would like now to benefit of the service by getting the necessary water supply to the Presbytery. Otherwise it would be very costly to have a separate installation made similar to that of the school, that is the reason why he is requesting the authorization of the Department to make the connection.

By authorizing such connection it would be necessary to change the present water tank and have it replaced by a larger one; the share of the electric subsidy to be paid by the reverend Fathers should also be taken into consideration; all these conditions should be agreed.

MEMORANDUM:

May 17, 1929.

Mr. [Signature]

While making an inspection of the work now being carried out by the various schools in Caughnawaga my attention was brought to the necessity of performing various works which have not been authorized.

EASTERN SCHOOL.
Reconstruction of the entrance to the basement at an estimated cost of $250.00.

The brick veneer was found to be in immediate need of painting. This work was authorized as well as the replacing of two doors of the pupils' entrance which were warped and cannot be rehung.

MIDDLE SCHOOL.
The brick veneer of this building was found to be in need of painting, and this work was authorized, also the replacing of two doors of the pupils' entrance which were beyond repair. The new doors will have glazed panels instead of being entirely of wood and will improve the appearance of the building.

SENIOR SCHOOL.
The floor of the auditorium of this building was damaged in many places while the roof was being reinforced, and should therefore be revarnished at a cost of $60.00. I have not authorized this expenditure. Screens are required for this building, and I would recommend that they be ordered from a Sash Factory in Lachine by the Agent. They will probably cost around $1.50 each. Authorization was given for the installation of two chains around the railing of the opening above the winding stairs in the rear of the stage as a means of protection against the pupils falling into the stair well. This will cost about $15.00.

Authorization was given for the painting of the fire escapes at each of the above mentioned schools.

TEACHERS' RESIDENCE.
A separate drain for the waste water from the laundry
should be installed in order that this water might not pass through the septic tank and thus interfere with the proper functioning of same.

This separate drain will cost in the neighborhood of $100.00 and I strongly recommend that it be installed as early as possible.

Sir,

The Department has been advised that the repairs now being performed at the Caughnawaga Schools are not progressing as speedily as they should, and that some of the painters and carpenters are not competent to fulfill the work entrusted to them. I would ask you, therefore, to consult with Mr. Needing who has charge of the work and make the necessary arrangements in order that the work may be completed by the end of this month. As previously mentioned the Department relies on you to verify the time sheets submitted to you by the contractor, as well as the accounts for materials which are to be ordered at the time that they are needed on the work.

No work, other than authorized by the Department Engineer when he last made an inspection, should be undertaken, with the exception of the cleaning and varnishing of the floor in the auditorium of the Senior School and the reconstruction of the entrances to the basement in the rear elevation of the Eastern School, which work should be undertaken at once in order that it might be fully completed on the above mentioned date.

The Department will further advise you with regard to the renovating of the Protestant School as well as the St. Isidore Road School and Teachers' residence, which work it is intended to have performed by contract.

A request has been made by the Superior of the schools that screens be purchased for all windows of the Senior School. I would ask you to obtain competitive prices from local dealers for a strongly constructed screen each provided with all necessary hardware for their adjustment in the lower part of the windows, all of which should receive two coats of paint. The price should be $2.00 per school building at Caughnawaga.

Kindly acknowledge receipt of this letter.

Monsieur,

J'ai l'honneur d'accuser réception de votre lettre du 22 courant relativement aux travaux de réparations qui sont actuellement exécutés par la Compagnie Clovis Electric à la résidence des Sœurs aînées ou aux écoles Senior, Kateri et Eastern dans le village de Caughnawaga.

Permettez-moi d'abord de vous dire que j'ai été quelque peu surpris d'apprendre que le Département avait été informé que les travaux en cours ne progressaient pas avec toute la diligence requise et que des peintres et des menuisiers ne sont pas compétents pour faire le travail qui leur est confié.

Il va sans dire qu'il m'était pratiquement impossible de demeurer constamment sur les lieux pour surveiller le travail qui y était fait; mais je puis vous assurer avec certitude que les travaux qui ont été exécutés l'ont été avec autant d'économie possible. Les listes de paie ainsi que les comptes pour les matériaux ont été bien surveillées et contrôlées et les listes de paie, plus particulièrement ont été après chaque semaine vérifiées par Reverende Sœur Supérieure des écoles. Les peintres et les menuisiers qui ont été employés par la Compagnie Clovis Electric n'avaient sans doute pas tous la même compétence au travail, d'ailleurs, les listes de paie attestent qu'ils sont payés d'après la capacité de chacun d'eux et ils étaient placés par M. Niding, qui est journalièrement en charge de ces travaux, suivant le genre de travail que ces employés pouvaient faire en tenant compte de l'habilité de chacun d'eux. Ce sont des Indiens de Caughnawaga et qui ont été généralement

Le Secrétaire,
Département des Affaires des Indiens,
OTTAWA.
employés dans le passé lorsque des réparations ont été com-
me cette année autorisées par le Département.

À chaque de mes visites à Caughnawaga, deux et quel-
ques fois trois fois par semaine j'ai fait l'examen, avec
M. Niding, des travaux en cours; il est venu aussi plusieurs
fois à mon bureau à St. Constant pour en conférer et je puis
certifier que si ces travaux contiennent, à date, une somme
approximative de $3000.00, du travail et des matériaux ont
été fournis au Département pour ce même chiffre.

ÉCOLE SENIOR:

Les travaux faits se repartissent comme suit:

1o - Une couche de peinture a été posée sur les enduits
dans tous les appartements ainsi que les corridors;
ce travail avait nécessité auparavant un lavage des
murs.

2o - Une deuxième couche de peinture a été posée sur les
instructions de Revde. Sœur Supérieure parceque cette
première couche ne paraissait pas suffisante.

3o - Nettoyer et vernir la salle des Concerts (Auditorium)
ainsi que l'entrée principale et par la suite cinq
autres appartements contigus à l'entrée principale,
ces derniers d'après les instructions données par Revde.
Sœur Supérieure. Les deux chambres de toilette pein-
tures vernis posé sur une hauteur d'environ 6'.

4o - Après que les travaux ont été complétés par MacKenzie
dans la salle Auditorium, le travail de réparations
aux enduits a nécessité près de huit jours par deux
plâtriers avec deux journaliers et le matériel requis
pour ce même travail a été de 75% de celui qui était
destiné à d'autres endroits.

( NOTE ) Les travaux qui restent à faire à cette école
sont une couche de peinture qui devrait être donnée aux
escaliers de sauvetage, puisque la rouille qui s'en empare
pourrait fortement les détériorer.
ÉCOLE KATERI:

1o - Les travaux de réparations aux enduits sont complètes.

2o - Des bases en ciment 2' x 2' ont été placées à l'épreuve de la gelée sous des piliers refaits de briques (qui sont comprises dans les comptes pour matériaux), sous les colonnes supportant les portiques à l'entrée principale ainsi qu'à chaque extrémité de cette école. Ces colonnes étaient pourries à leur base, mais ils ont pu être utilisées par M. Niding en y ajoutant d'autres blocs en bois moulurés. Une autre base en ciment est placée à l'épreuve de la gelée sous l'escalier de l'entrée principale.

3o - Une base en ciment a été placée à l'épreuve de la gelée sous l'escalier de sauvetage.

4o - La couverture a été réparée.

5o - Les marches et contre-marches des trois escaliers ont été refaits à neuf. (à l'extérieur).

Les travaux qui restent à faire par la Compagnie Clovis Electric à cette école sont les suivants:

1o - Peinturer l'intérieur et l'extérieur.

2o - Les deux portes aux extrémités à être remplacées.

---

(NOTE) La brique qui a pu être utilisée avec profit après la démolition des piliers aux trois entrées de cette école a été transportée par M. Niding à l'école Eastern où elle a pu être employée à d'autres fins.
ECOLE EASTERN:

1o - Les bases en ciment ont aussi été refaites et mises à l'épreuve de la gelée sous les entrées aux extrémités de cette école ainsi qu'à l'entrée principale.

2o - Les escaliers extérieurs étaient en très mauvais état et rendus dangereux à cause de la pourriture, il a fallu remplacer tout ce bois par du neuf.

3o - Une base en ciment a été faite sous l'escalier de l'entrée principale.

4o - Les murs ont été peintures deux couches, à l'intérieur.

(Note) Les enduits dans les salles de classe à cette école étaient en très mauvais état et ont nécessité beaucoup de travail de réparations à part le lavage qu'il a fallu faire ensuite aux murs.

5o - Les plafonds ont été peintures.

6o - Les travaux de menuiserie aux portes et fenêtres sont complets.

Les travaux qui restent à faire sont les suivants à cette école:

1o - Peinturer l'extérieur.

2o - Réparer le trottoir à l'entrée principale.

3o - Démolir et refaire l'entrée au soubassement en arrière de l'école.

Veuillez me permettre cette occasion pour suggérer que cette entrée soit reconstruite semblable à celle
qui a été construite par la même Compagnie dans le cours de l'automne dernier à l'école Kateri. Le puits artésien d'un diamètre de 5" et creuse à une grande profondeur fourni de l'eau de bonne qualité à cette école Eastern. Il pourrait bien ne pas être question maintenant de l'installation d'une pompe automatique semblable à celle de l'école Kateri, au moins, lorsqu'il serait question d'en faire l'installation, le puits étant déjà creuse, il serait je crois plus économique de faire seulement et des maintenant cette entrée de quelques pieds plus longue.

Residence des Soeurs.

Les travaux qui y ont été faits sont les suivants:

1o - Peinturer deux couches à l'extérieur de la résidence, les dépendances ainsi que la clôture, cependant, les travaux des peintres à la clôture ne seront pas terminées avant vendredi, le 31 courant.

2o - Réparations faites aux dépendances.

3o - Les portes à la résidence sont réparées.

4o - Les enduits ont été réparés et deux couches de peinture ont été posées sur les murs dans cinq chambres ainsi que le corridor de l'entrée principale et les plafonds dans ces mêmes appartements, ont aussi été peintures y compris la salle à dîner.

Les travaux qui restent à faire à la résidence sont les suivants,

1o - Cement water-proof sur les couvertures.
(Note) Il faudra attendre des journées plus chaudes pour faire ce travail.

2o - Peinturer les planchers, une couche dans les chambres à coucher.

3o - Vernir les prélates.

4o - Peinturer les boiseries.

..............
Je crains que les travaux qui restent à faire, comme vous voudrez bien le constater par ce qui précède, ne soient pas terminés avec la fin du mois présent comme vous sembliez l'exiger dans votre lettre du 22 courant.

Cependant M. Niding est bien disposé de faire en sorte que les travaux soient poussés avec le plus d'activité possible, mais je ne crois pas qu'ils puissent être terminés avant le 8 du mois de juin prochain.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th inst., concerning the repairs which are at present being done to the Sister's residence and to the Senior Sisters' and Eastern schools in the Caughnawaga village by the Clowes Electric Company.

Permit me to tell you first that I was somewhat surprised to learn that the Department was informed the work in course of execution was not progressing with the speed required and that some of the painters and carpenters are not competent to do the work they have to carry on.

It goes without saying that I could not stay on the scene continually to supervise the work being done; but I can assure you that the work performed has been made with as economical an expenditure as possible. The pay lists as well as the accounts for materials were well checked and controlled, and the pay lists more particularly were verified each week by the Reverend Sister Superior of the School. The painters and carpenters employed by the Clowes Electric Co., did not all have the same competency for the work they had to perform; however the pay list indicates that they were paid according to their individual merit and they were placed by Mr. Ryding, who is continually in charge of the work, according to the nature of the work and ability of each one to do it.

It was Indians of Caughnawaga who were employed, as in the past when repairs were authorized by the Department.
At every visit of my visits at Oshawa, two and sometimes three times a week, I examined with Mr. Miller, the work in progress; he also came several times at my office at St. Constant to confer about it and I can affirm that if this work cost to date, an approximate sum of $300.00 in work and material has been supplied to the Department to that extent.

Senior School

The work done is as follows:

1. One coat of paint was given in every room as well as the hall. This work was preceded by a thorough cleaning of the walls.

2. A second coat of paint was put on at the request of Rev. Sister Superior as the first coat did not appear sufficient.

3. Cleaning and varnishing of the Concert Hall (Auditorium) as well as the principal entrance and following, the rooms contiguous to the principal entrance, this was done according to instructions given by Rev. Sister Superior. Both toilet rooms were painted and also varnished up to 6 ft. high.

4. After the work was completed by Mr. Macleay in the Auditorium, the repair work to the plastering necessitated the employment of two plasterers with two laborers for nearly 8 days and the material required for that same work took 75% of that which was intended to be used at other places.

(Note) The work which remains to be done at that school is: one coat of paint to be given to the fire escapes, as the rust covering them will damage them considerably.
Kateri School

1. The repairs to the plastering are completed.

2. Cement basis 5'x3' were built, from proof, under the brick pillars which were rebuilt (this is covered in the accounts for materials) supporting the columns of the porches situated at the outside entrance as well as at the extremities of the school. These columns were rotten at their bases, but they were utilized by Mr. Hickey by adding other blocks of wood with mouldings.

Another cement basis also proof-proof was placed under the stair of the principal entrance.

3. A proof-proof cement basis was placed under the fire escape.

4. The roof was repaired.

5. The steps and risers of the three exterior stairs were rebuilt.

The work remaining to be done by the Oblate Co. to this school are as follows:

1. Painting the interior and exterior of the building.

2. The two doors at the ends need to be replaced.

Note: The bricks which could be used again from the pillars of the three entrances were transported by Mr. Hickey to the Eastern school where they were used again.

Eastern School

1. The cement basis were also rebuilt, supporting under the entrances at the end and front of this school.

2. The exterior stairs were in very bad state and had become dangerous on account of the decay of the timbers; it was necessary to replace all that timber.
A cement base was built under the main entrance.

The walls were given two coats of paint at the interior.

(Note) The plastering in the school rooms of this building was in very bad state and have necessitated a great deal of repair work beside the cleaning of the walls which had to be done after.

The ceilings were finished.

The carpentry work to the doors and windows was completed.

The work remaining to be done to the school is as follows:

1. Painting of the exterior.
2. Repair the sidewalk at the main entrance.
3. Demolish and rebuild the entrance to the basement at the rear of the school.

Permit me to suggest that this entrance be rebuilt in the same manner as that done by the same company during the course of last fall at the Sisters' school. The artesian well which is 6" in diameter and drilled at a great depth supplies water of good quality to this Eastern school. There may not be any question of installing an automatic pump similar to that of the Sisters' school; at least when it is thought of installing one as the well is already dug, it would be more economical to have the intake pipe lengthened a few feet than now.

Sisters' residence:

The work done was as follows:

1. Painting, with two coats of the exterior of the residence, the dependencies as well as the...
However, the painting of the fence will not be completed before Friday, the 31st inst.

2. Repairs done to the residence.

3. The residence's doors are repaired.

4. The plastering was repaired and two coats of paint were applied on the walls of five rooms as well as the hall of the main entrance, all the ceilings of those rooms were painted as well as the dining room.

The work remaining to be done at the residence is as follows:

1. Waterproof cement on the roofs.

Note: It will be necessary to wait until the temperature is warmer to do this work.

2. Paint the floors, one coat in the bed rooms.

3. Varnish the linoleums.

4. Paint the wainscoting.

I fear that the remaining work may not be completed by the end of the present month as requested in your letter of the 27th inst.

However, Mr. Hiding is doing his best to have the work done as soon as possible, but I fear this may not be terminated until the 8th of June next.

Automatic Water Systems

Waterboy—Model 205

This is a complete shallow well water system of 225 gallon-per-hour capacity, equipped with 1-6 H.P. motor and five gallon tank—offered at an exceptionally low price.

The small tank insures a supply of fresh water at all times. The motor is furnished in all ordinary voltages and cycles.

Other models of the same capacity (225 gallons-per-hour), either without tank or with any standard size pressure tank up to 1000 gallon capacity may be furnished.

440 Gallon-per-Hour Pumps

These models are twin-cylinder, duplex type, shallow well pumps with 440 gallon-per-hour capacity, 3/4 H.P. motor.

The extra large pumping capacity will take care of the requirements of many installations where a large volume of water is desired.

May be furnished without tank or equipped with any standard size storage and pressure tank, as shown to the right (Model 400-B, 80-gallon tank), according to requirements.

Deep Well Pumps

When complete automatic pressure water service is desired, where the supply must be pumped from a depth greater than 22 feet, these pumps designed especially for deep well use are available. It is easy to install, requires practically no attention, and is as near perfect as engineering and manufacturing experience can make it.

A complete deep well system consists of the power head (illustrated right) with motor and air pump, together with appropriate size pressure tank and well cylinder, either of the open or closed type.

There are several patented and superior features about the line of Deep Well Water Systems. Packing box and piston rod are made of brass with packing of extra high quality. Operating normally at a 5" stroke, this may be easily adjusted to the 6" position when a smaller cylinder must be used, or to the 4" position, when the voltage is low.

Four Models—125 to 550 gallons-per-hour. Model 25, for wells up to 100 feet; Model 50, for wells up to 200 feet in depth; Model 75, for wells up to 300 feet in depth; Model 100, for wells up to 575 feet in depth.

Memorandum: Mr. Paget.

The Department requires an oil burner for the Senior School lately erected at Caughnawaga, one large enough to heat a no. 8 hot water boiler. I have examined a number of types of installations, several of which I found to be thoroughly dependable and worthy of consideration. Among these is the Sphinx manufactured by Shaver Bros. Ltd., of Ottawa in three different types, selling at $555.00 - $650.00 - $750.00. After seeing this burner in course of assembly and in operation at the factory, I would recommend that the order be placed with this firm for one of medium size at their price $650.00, without fuel oil tanks. This price comprises complete installation of the apparatus and one year maintenance service.

Should it be found advisable to invite competitive prices for an apparatus of this kind I would ask you to furnish me with the names of dealers in Montreal. It is essential that this equipment be supplied as early as possible as no provision has been made for supplying coal this fall.

Memorandum: Mr. Foggier

As you are aware the brick veneer of the Senior School at Caughnawaga was not satisfactorily completed owing to a sudden change in the weather which occurred before the jointing had time to settle, thus resulting in the freezing of the mortar and necessitating the repointing of the brick veneer on the front elevation. In view of the fact that the rest of the building is well finished I would recommend that the whole of the exterior of the brick work be painted next spring, the cost of which will not exceed $450.00. I am glad to say that all of the other schools in Caughnawaga have been completely renovated this year, and their present appearance is certainly a credit to the Department.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, June 22, 1929.

Memorandum.

Dr. Scott,

In accordance with your instructions, I have investigated last week the possibilities of providing temporary and emergency means for the supplying of pure water to the Indians residing at Caughnawaga, Que., where typhoid has been prevalent in the past year on account of the polluted condition of the water used for domestic purposes which is mostly taken from the St. Lawrence River and ordinary shallow wells scattered in the village, and beg to make the following recommendation.

Installing of a pneumatic pumping plant over the artesian well already available outside the Boys' school (Eastern School) to replace the present hand operating outfit. Installing of a small hydrant outside the building where water could be obtained by the Indians at any time without interfering with the school operation. The above mentioned installation would necessitate the erection of a small building over the well and pumping plant at a total cost of about $600.00.

Installing also of a small hydrant outside the Girls' School (Katari School) where an artesian well with a complete pumping plant is already in operation. It would be necessary in this case to install a larger pressure tank at a total cost of $200.00.

Boring of another artesian well at the eastern end of the village and the installation of a complete pumping system similar to that installed in the above mentioned schools at an approximate cost of $1200.00.

Water could this way be obtained from any of the above sources of supply by the Indians individually as well as by those who are now making a distribution and selling it throughout the reserve.

Gentlemen:

With reference to our contract to supply two Tanks to Caughnawaga School, which have been delivered by us direct to the school, by truck.

Our quotation dated September 24th, 1929 quotes on these two Tanks, f.o.b., Adirondack Junction.

After talking the matter over with your Mr. Chenie, in your office, we discussed approximately the additional cost of delivering these Tanks direct to the job, instead of to Adirondack Junction, of approximately two miles from the School.

During this conversation, while discussing the large Tank, it was mentioned that the additional cost of delivering via truck direct to School, would probably be in the neighborhood of $7.00, and nothing was mentioned about the small Tank.

As the allowance made for freight plus the $7.00 allowance that you have granted us as per your telegram dated October 14th, 1929, does not meet the cartage charges to Caughnawaga on two trucks, which was absolutely necessary, we would ask you to pass our invoice for an additional amount of $3.50 cartage on the small Tank.

The large Tank of three thousand gallons capacity required a large truck, which we had to hire at the rate of $3.50 per hour, and the small tank had to be loaded on another truck of a smaller size, which cost us $1.50 per hour.

Somehow or other, there was considerable delay on the job, owing to your contractor there having to phone Ottawa before he would allow us to unload the Tanks.

This telephone conversation was extremely expensive to us, as it cost us $6.20 per hour lost time, as we had two men with the trucks, in addition to the drivers, to assist unloading.

I would strongly urge that no one be allowed in future to sell water for domestic purposes which is taken from the St. Lawrence River, or from any other source on the reserve unless it has been previously analyzed with satisfactory results.

The above mentioned arrangement, if adopted, will require the services of a competent person to take care of the various pumping plants, and I understand that one of the caretakers of the schools could be entrusted with this work if he is allowed reasonable remuneration.

I shall prepare in the course of this summer, for your information if you wish, a report giving an estimate of an elaborate scheme which would provide a supply of pure water for domestic purposes as well as for fire protection with its central distribution point (an elevated steel tank) located in the centre of the village. The system could be later gradually extended through the whole town whenever found necessary.

I would not recommend, however, the undertaking of such a project which would eventually require larger expenditure for its construction as well as for its operation until the Indians had demonstrated their willingness to cooperate with the Department and follow the advice already given them to discontinue the use of water from the St. Lawrence River and other polluted sources should they be allowed to draw their supply of water from any one of the above mentioned artesian wells without any charge whatsoever to them.

I would suggest, furthermore, that the Provincial Board of Health from Montreal be requested to make in future, frequent bacteriological analysis of the water from the artesian wells until the health conditions have become normal on the reserve.

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.

Ottawa, May 13, 1930.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, applying for a grant of $105 to purchase prizes or other suitable gifts for the pupils of the Roman Catholic Schools and St. Isidore Road School on the Caughnawaga Reserve to be awarded to them before the schools close for the coming summer holidays.

In reply I have to say that our funds for the present fiscal year are extremely limited, and I regret to inform you that we will be unable to provide the grant asked for this year. I know that you, the Reverend Sisters and the pupils will be disappointed; but it is necessary that all expenditure be curtailed as far as possible, and it is, therefore, not possible to supply funds for the purchase of prizes or other gifts.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sister M. Francis,
Supervising Principal,
R. C. Indian Schools,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 6th instant in connection with the voucher which I have forwarded in favour of the Bell Telephone Co., and in reply to say that the long distance telephone service used by the caretaker, only, were of those to Laprairie, which is my telephone call, and St. Remi where this district office of the Beauharnois Electric Company is located.

I may assure the Department that the telephone calls made at Senior School by Albany Robert, the caretaker, were only intended for the administration of the Indian Day schools at Caughnawaga.

As directed in your letter, the accounts for this service are to be included in the regular quarterly statement of general disbursements by the Sister Superior.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

OTTAWA.
Ottawa, May 22nd, 1930.

Madam,

With further reference to your letter of the 12th instant applying for a grant to purchase prizes or other suitable gifts for the pupils of the Roman Catholic Schools and the St. Isidore Road School on the Caughnawaga Reserve, I have to say that, upon further consideration, it has been decided to authorize you to incur an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $75.00 for this purpose, in order that the children will not be disappointed in not receiving these gifts before the schools close for the coming summer holidays. As stated in official letter of the 13th instant, it is necessary to restrict all expenditure as our funds are limited and, therefore, we found it necessary to refuse grants for the purchase of prizes at all Indian schools this summer.

You should obtain itemized accounts from the merchants from whom you make the purchases and hand these accounts to Mr. Agent Letourneau to be certified by him and sent to the Department for payment.

We are informing Mr. Agent Letourneau of the authority granted you to incur the expenditure of $75.00 in the purchase of prizes.

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Williams,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
