MEMORANDUM:

June 16, 1930.

Mr. Ferguson,

While at Caughnawaga I was advised by the Caretaker of the Schools that the oil burning system which was adopted last year for the heating of the Central School is most satisfactory and has proved to be a great economy. As I understand that quite a saving would be made by installing a similar system in either the boys or girls school I would recommend that this change be allowed as soon as funds are available and before coal is delivered to either of the buildings.

Sept. 4, 1930.

Sir,

I beg to refer you to my letter of October 22, 1928 ordering from your company a pneumatic water supply system for the girls' school at Caughnawga, which plant was installed by the Clovis Electric Co. of Montreal.

I regret to advise that the caretaker who has had charge of this plant reports that this outfit has never given satisfaction, although it has been examined and repaired at various times by competent plumbers. It appears from an investigation lately made that the piston rod which was supplied by your company is not of the kind suitable for this installation, also there are some defects in the pump which prevents it from operating to its full capacity. By referring to the letter above mentioned, you will note that payment was made for this machinery on the assumption that it would give satisfactory and continuous service. Before expending further amounts for the repairing of this pumping plant, I would very much appreciate it if you would have one of your mechanics make a thorough inspection of it, and advise the Department as early as possible as to the reasons for the existing conditions.

In view of the fact that water is absolutely necessary for the operation of this school I trust that you will give this matter your immediate attention.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re Water System Girls' School at Caughnawaga.

Refer to file No. 5-1-5E, your letter Sept. 4th.

Referring to your letter of the 4th inst., as requested, we have had one of our mechanics look over the installation of the Water Supply System, which we sold for the Girls' School at Caughnawaga, and in this connection, we would give you the following information:

The Caretaker complains that the pump has to run 8 hours instead of four, and that at least every three months he has to change the cup leathers in the cylinder, otherwise the outfit is working all right.

We would suggest that these cup leathers be looked into as regards quality, as if they are not of the best, they will of course wear out sooner.

We found on checking up the capacity that this outfit would give approximately 100 U.S. gallons per hour, and the capacity of the three tanks he is filling is approximately 450 gallons, so that this of course shows that the pump is working under capacity, and the reason for same might probably be that if the cup leathers are wearing out as quickly as the caretaker reports, it means that there may be gritty water in the well, and this grit may have scored the deep well cylinder itself, causing the water to leak by the leather, and so diminish the capacity.

With regard to your contention that the piston rod supplied by our Company, was not suitable, we would report that what did give the trouble, and had to be replaced, was the rod which connects the...
Deep well head to the deep well cylinder, which was not supplied by us, but by the contractor who installed the outfit. This has been replaced lately by a galvanized iron pipe, which we think should be all right.

You of course know that it is only usual to guarantee apparatus for one year from date of shipment, and on this account, any work that you wish us to do on this outfit, we would require to be paid for... If you wish us to have a mechanic dismantle the outfit and examine the Deep Well cylinder, we would be glad to receive your order to do so.

Yours very truly,

DARLING B. OTHERS LIMITED.

Re.- WATER SYSTEM - GIRLS SCHOOL, CAUGHNAWAGA, FILE #5-1.5E -

Gentlemen:

Referring further to your letters of Sept. 4th and 23rd, we would advise that we have had one of our mechanics dismantle this Deep Well Pump and go over all parts of it and put it in a satisfactory state of affairs.

Our mechanic reports that 90% of the trouble was caused by badly leaking joints on the Discharge Pipe below the ground. When he pulled up the Deep Well Cylinder it was hanging to the Discharge Pipe by only two threads and might have dropped to the bottom of the well at any moment, also practically all the Joints in the Discharge Pipe were leaking badly. The intake to the Cylinder was quite clear and not clogged, neither were the Cup Leathers in very bad condition, in fact, the same Leathers were used when we started the system again.

The net result of our efforts was that the Pump is now discharging at a rate of approximately 75% more capacity than before the repair was made.

We trust that these results will be satisfactory, we are,

Yours very truly,

OXENE & OXENATORS

The purpose of this schedule is to outline the various types of Oxenators, and to describe the Oxene tablets.

OXENE

Oxene is a patented compound put up in tablet form. This compound contains 27% chlorine. Tablets are manufactured in 1/4", 5/8", and 1 3/8" diameters.

STERILIZING.

The water is sterilized by contact. A tablet immersed in a stream of water gives off 98% of its chlorine in approximately 16 hours. The chlorine is liberated very rapidly at first, and comparatively slowly as the chlorine becomes exhausted. The contact method of sterilization is particularly well adapted to sterilize small water supplies where the demand is of an intermittent character.

On larger systems having a comparatively uniform demand it is more economical to grind the tablets, thus using all available chlorine which is supplied by the grinder at a uniform rate corresponding to the pre-determined water demand.

OXENATORS.

Oxenators are devised for use in applying Oxene tablets.

POCKET OXENATOR.

The Pocket Oxenator is similar in appearance to a fountain pen. This device consists of a magazine for holding spare 1/4" Oxene tablets, and a perforated receptacle at one end for holding a single tablet. The device is designed for travellers and can be used in sterilizing doubtful water. A fresh tablet is placed in the perforated receptacle and stirred around in a glass of water for 30 seconds. This effectively sterilizes the water.

TAP OXENATORS.

The Tap Oxenator consists of a hard-rubber receptacle arranged to screw on a water tap, or the device can be provided with a soft-rubber adapter to slip over any ordinary tap. The device contains a receptacle for a 5/8" Oxene tablet, and the water is sterilized by passing over the tablet as it is drawn from the tap. With ordinary domestic demands a tablet will last from one to two days, and should then be renewed.

JUG OXENATOR.

This Oxenator consists of an enamel-ware jug having a receptacle in the spout for a 5/8" Oxene tablet. The device is particularly adapted for campers. The water is effectively sterilized as it passes over the Oxene tablet in the spout of the jug.

CONTACT OXENATORS.

The Contact Oxenator for 1 3/8" tablets consists of galvanized steel containers with a removable hole cover., a basket containing the tablets; and an arrangement of valves to regulate the flow of water through the Oxenator. With this type of Oxenator sterilization is accomplished by forming a strong hypo-chlorine solution in the Oxenator.
On pumping systems of uniform demand, water is taken from the pressure side of the pump through a needle valve to the bottom of the Oxenator. The water passes from the Oxenator flowing out at the top through the flexible connection and a rubber shut-off valve back to the suction of the pump. The needle valve is adjusted to supply the required amount of solution to the pump intake.

On pressure systems an orifice gate may be installed in the pressure line by passing a small portion of the water through the Oxenator. This arrangement can be piped to effectively sterilize fluctuating demands within reasonable limits.

Another type of Oxenator is similar to those described above, except that the basket is omitted, and a screen is provided near the bottom of the Oxenator. These Oxenators can be filled with from 50 to 100 pounds of Oxene tablets. This Oxenator is used in sterilizing water mains. Water is passed through the Oxenator into the lower end of the main. After a pre-determined interval, the supply valve to the main is opened to allow a small flow of water. The flow is set to fill the main in a pre-determined time. The water as it passes through the main valve carries a crest of very strong hypo-chlorine solution through the main. After the crest is started the flow through the Oxenator is adjusted to supply chlorine at the rate of from 2 to 5 P.F.M.

This follows up the strong crest with an over-sterilized flow of water. The City of Montreal, and the Montreal Water Board have been using this type of Oxenator in sterilizing new mains, and all old mains which have undergone repairs.

Another type of Oxenator consists of a double galvanized metal screen approximately 3' x 8' 1 3/8". Tablets are clamped between the screen. The screen is suspended from the stern of a boat. This outfit is used in sterilizing reservoirs. Last fall the Gueremont reservoir on the Montreal system was badly contaminated by algae. The trouble was corrected in a few hours, without interrupting the water service.

OXENATORS - GRINDERS.

These Oxenators consist of a small mechanical driven grinder wheel, a magazine containing 1 3/8" Oxene tablets, and a supply of water to wash the grindings from the wheel. The wash water contains a strong hypo-chlorine solution. The strength of this solution depends on:

1. The grit of the wheel.
2. The speed of the wheel.
3. The weight of tablets in the magazine.
4. The quantity of wash water supplied.

Solution from these Oxenators may be connected directly to the suction of a pump, provided a uniform amount of water is being pumped steadily for 24 hours. In the event of fluctuating demands, the solution is stored in a reservoir and provided with suitable regulating devices which may be of an automatic, or semi-automatic character.

These Grinders may be driven by:

(A). A water wheel providing water pressure is available at 30 pounds or more.
(B). An electric motor.
(C). By a belt or gearing when mechanical power is available.

APPLICATIONS.

The Contact Oxenator is best adapted when supplying intermittent demands to the systems of comparatively small capacity. The Grinding Oxenators are best suited for supplying systems of uniform flow over a 24 hour period.

Mr. Harrington has referred to us your inquiry of the 22nd inst., regarding the cost of installing a sterilizing equipment in a school within a radius of 15 miles of Montreal.

We use a compound known as Oxene for sterilizing water. The various devices used in applying the compound are known as Oxeonators. The contract licensing us to manufacture this compound has only recently been signed and no literature is available. We are, however, enclosing a typewritten schedule describing the various appliances which are, or shortly will be, on the market.

The type of Oxeonator required for the school is governed largely by the character of the water system, and the amount of water required per day. We recommend that you consider installing Tap Oxeonators, which will sterilize water by passing it over an Oxene tablet as it is drawn from the tap, or drinking fountain. These Tap Oxeonators would cost from $3.00 to $20.00 installed at the school, depending on the quantity. The Contact Oxeonator makes use of the 1 3/8" Oxene tablets, which can be supplied in 100 pound lots for $20.00, or in 50 pound lots for $12.50. With this type of Oxeonator, water can be sterilized at a cost not exceeding $.01 per thousand gallons. I would also suggest that you provide the school with an Ortho-Tolldin test kit. With this outfit any of the teachers can check the water for chlorine residue. We can supply you with the test kit for $15.00.

The tap oxemator consists of a hard rubber receptacle arranged to screw on a water tap, or the device can be provided with a soft rubber adapter to slip over an ordinary tap. The device contains a recess for a 5/8" Oxene tablet, and the water is sterilized by passing over the tablet.
as it is drawn from the tap. With ordinary domestic demands a tablet will last from one to two days, and should then be renewed.

**JUG OXENATOR.**

This Oxenator consists of an enamel-ware jug having a receptacle in the spout for a 5/8" oxene tablet. The device is particularly adapted for campers. The water is effectively sterilized as it passes over the oxene tablet in the spout of the jug.

**CONTACT OXENATORS.**

The contact Oxenator for 1-3/8" tablets consists of galv. steel containers with removable hand hole cover, a basket containing the tablets, and an arrangement of valves to regulate the flow of water through the Oxenator. With this type of Oxenator sterilization is accomplished by forming a strong hypo-chlorine solution in the Oxenator.

On pumping systems of uniform demand, water is taken from the pressure side of the pump through a needle valve to the bottom of the Oxenator. The water passes from the Oxenator flowing out at the top through the flexible connection and a rubber, shut-off valve back to the suction of the pump. The needle valve is adjusted to supply the required amount of solution to the pump intake.

On pressure systems an orifice gate may be installed in the pressure line by passing a small portion of the water through the Oxenator. This arrangement can be piped to effectively sterilize fluctuating demands within reasonable limits.

Another type of Oxenator is similar to those described above except that the basket is omitted, and screen is provided near the bottom of the Oxenator. These Oxenators can be filled with from 50 to 100 pounds of oxene tablets. This Oxenator is used in sterilizing water mains. Water is passed through the Oxenator into the lower end of an empty main. After a pre-determined interval, the supply valve to the main is opened to allow a small flow of water. The flow is set to fill the main in a pre-determined time. The water as it passes through the main valve carries a crest of very strong hypo-chlorine solution through the main. After the crest is started the flow through the Oxenator is adjusted to supply chlorine at the rate of from 2 to 5 P.P.M. This follows up the strong crest with an over-sterilized flow of water. The city of Montreal and the Montreal Water Board have been using this type of Oxenator in sterilizing new mains, and all old mains which have undergone repairs.

Another type of Oxenator consists of a double galvanized metal screen approximately 3' x 8'. 1-3/8" tablets are clamped between the screen. The screen is suspended from the stern of a boat. This outfit is used in sterilizing reservoirs. Last fall, at Outremont the reservoir on the Montreal system was badly contaminated by algae. The trouble was...
corrected in a few hours, without interrupting the water service.

OXENATORS — GRINDERS.

These oxenators consist of small mechanical driven grinder wheel, a magazine containing 1-3/8" oxene tablets, and a supply of water to wash the grindings from the wheel. The wash water contains a strong hypo-chlorine solution. The strength of the solution depends on:

1. The grit of the wheel.
2. The speed of the wheel.
3. The weight of tablets in magazine.
4. The quantity of wash water supplied.

Solution from these Oxenators may be connected directly to the suction of a pump, providing a uniform amount of water is being pumped steadily for 24 hours. In the event of fluctuating demands, the solution is stored in a reservoir and provided with suitable regulating devices which may be of an automatic, or semi-automatic character.

These grinders may be driven by:

1. A water wheel providing water pressure is available at 30 lbs or more.
2. An electric motor.
3. By a belt or gearing when mechanical power is available.

APPLICATIONS.

The contact Oxenator is best adapted when supplying intermittent demands to the systems of comparatively small capacity.

The grinding Oxenators are best suited for supplying systems of uniform flow over a 24 hour period.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your inquiries of Jan. 14th. and Feb. 6th. Our investigation shows the following conditions at the Senior Central Catholic School Building at Caughnawaga:

The water system consists of:
- A 100 foot driven well.
- A Fairbanks-Morse deep well pump.
- A 250 Gallon Pneumatic pressure tank supplying water to a drinking fountain.
- Wash basins and toilet.

From information supplied, the requirements of the school are about 500 gallons per day. The janitor reports the water is very clear, but that the tests have shown that the supply is contaminated.

We recommend that you install a 12 1/2 gallon contact-type Oxenator as outlined on our print #1151. Our price for installing this system is $150.00 for the Oxenator and labour. $3.00 for 1-15 pound package of Oxene tablets, and $15.00 for an Ortho-Tolidin test kit for testing the water to check the residue chlorine. For the above mentioned prices we will supply and install the sterilizing system. The water tank and pipes will be emptied, and the tank and all piping thoroughly sterilized. The system will then be rinsed out with steril water, and adjusted to sterilize the water as it is drawn from the well.

Written instructions will be supplied for operating the system. We will demonstrate the operation of the system to the janitor and the Principal, showing them how to take the Ortho-Tolidin test for chlorine residue.
Arrangements will be made with the Chemical Laboratory of the City of Montreal to test samples of water for bacteria for 30 days after the system is installed. Reports of the bacteria test will be forwarded to the Principal of the school, and to your Department at Ottawa.

The cost of operating this small system is very small .... based on 500 gallons per day for 240 days per year you would only require 7 1/2 pounds of Oxene tablets. These tablets cost $.20 per pound in small quantities.

My dear Mr. Farnham,

The final reports for the year 1930-1931 doubtless reached you yesterday. It pleases me to add that we are truly grateful for being able to look back upon a term that has been rather pleasant and successful with the greater number of our pupils. Their attendance during the last quarter was far better than previously reported. Our only real annoyance was with a few of the larger boys who longed to be out at the Club to earn money for new apparel. It required a certain amount of firmness, both on my part and that of the teachers, to keep them in the classroom till the end.

Our Physical Culture Demonstration was all that we could desire and received high commendations on all sides. I am quite satisfied with Captain A. Champagne's work and trust you will do us the favor to re-engage his services next September. This training means so much for the improvement of discipline and is a powerful factor in facilitating the teacher's work in the classroom. With boys such as we have, Physical Culture under an Experienced Professor is really an indispensable part of the school curriculum.

Now kindly allow me to call your attention to a very serious point. Mr. Chene had given us his word that the
poorly-lighted classroom occupied by Miss Stacey would be put into fit condition during the last Christmas holidays. The matter was not attended to and, as a result, Miss Stacey complains, with perfect justice of cause, that the continuous use of the electric light during these past ten months has greatly impaired her eyesight. She made a special call since the closing of school to notify me of the fact. Moreover, the platform in the rear of her classroom, not only compels her to crowd the children around about her desk, but also occupies so much space that we cannot take in as many pupils as would be possible were this obstruction removed.

Last spring, owing to lack of accommodation we were compelled to refuse twelve little ones, much to the disappointment of parents who are not prone to accept our reasons readily and calmly.

Would you please look into this affair during the summer months so as to prevent further difficulties from arising.

Thanking you most sincerely for all the Department has done for our welfare and that of our pupils during this last year, I remain,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Canadian de cette réserve, demandant la location pour deux semaines d'une machine à écrire Underwood parmi celles qui ont été en usage aux écoles durant l'année scolaire 1930-1931.

J'ai cru devoir suggérer à Soeur Superieure de ne pas accorder cette demande de Angus Canadian jusqu'à ce qu'elle soit acceptée par le Département.

Je ne crois pas pouvoir recommander cette requête à votre approbation pour la raison que ce précédent pourrait créer des abus et ainsi les machines à écrire à l'usage des écoles seraient vite exposées à la ruine.

Sir:

Kindly find under cover a letter dated the 26 inst., addressed to the Reverend Superior of the schools of Caughnawaga by a young man named Angus H. Canadian, of this reserve, asking for the rental of an Underwood Typewriter for two weeks. This machine is one of those in use at the school during the years 1930-1931.

I thought it was advisable to suggest to the Rev. Sister Superior not to grant this request of Angus H. Canadian until it is approved by the department.

I believe it is my duty not to recommend this request for your approval for the reason that this precedent may create abuses and in such cases the Typewriting machines in use at the schools would soon be put out of order.

However, I leave it to the Department to decide of this case.

Your obedient servant,

Lorenzo Letourneau,

Sir,

I wish to inform you that I received a few days ago from the Clovis Electric Company, Montreal, an account amounting to $54.74 for repairs to a pump at one of the Caughnawaga Schools.

As I was not informed that such repairs were necessary I had to inquire yesterday from Mr. Robert, the guardian, he told me that in fact during the course of the holidays in July and August last some children had damaged the water pump which was used to supply the families of the neighborhood of the Eastern School so that the water was running continually. The electric pump at the Eastern School ran continually for several days without stopping, that is to such an extent that it got hot and damaged the machinery to such an extent that it became out of use.

It was then that without advising me Mr. Robert requested the services of the Clovis Electric Co., who afterwards had certain work done by the company who sold the pump to the Department. I do not know yet if these repairs have been well done but I shall make sure at my next visit at Caughnawaga. However, I have warned Mr. Robert that in future such repairs whether urgent or not shall not be done without authorization and the name of the person or company to be authorized to do such work shall be given by the Department.

If the work in question is found satisfactory I wish you would kindly inform me if I could be authorized to submit the account to be paid.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) L. Letourneau,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

We are enclosing copy of a letter received from Mr. A. F. MacKenzie, Secretary - Department of India Affairs, together with a copy of our reply. The writer visited the school in February and inspected the water system. From information obtained we do not believe that we would experience any trouble in sterilizing your water supply unless conditions obtained of which we were not advised.

We were told that the water pumped from the well was clear and palatable, but that fermentation tests showed that the water was contaminated. We do not believe from this information that the water is so badly contaminated that it would require more than a normal dose of chlorine to destroy the bacteria.

Can you give us the capacity of the pump in gallons per minute, or provide us with the name of the contractor who installed the plumbing system so that we can obtain this information from them. We require this data in order to provide the proper size of venturi nozzle for use with the Oxenator.

Yours very truly,

HALIBURTON & WHITE LIMITED.
HALIBURTON & WHITE LIMITED
MANUFACTURING ENGINEERS

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Reference #5-1-5.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 21st inst. We are willing to put in the Oxenator and Equipment as covered by our quotation of Feb. 18th at 60 days' trial with the understanding that we will accept the return of the material F.O.B. our factory if it does not sterilize the water if operated in accordance with our instructions.

We wish, however, to bring to your attention the fact that chlorinating the water does not necessarily improve its quality. The addition of chlorine destroys the bacteria, and it is possible but not probable that chlorine might have to be added to badly contaminated water in such quantities that it would be unpalatable. If you will cover us with an order we will proceed immediately with this work.

Yours very truly,

HALIBURTON & WHITE LIMITED.

Sir,

Permit me to refer to your letter of the 26th June last concerning the changes which should necessarily be done to the old concert hall of the Kateri School, Caughnawaga and to submit to your attention the following remarks which have just been made by Doctor Jacobs on the matter.

"I wish also to call your attention to the school sanitation in the two upper class-rooms in the R.C. school opposite the R.C. Church which I found unsatisfactory. In these class-rooms I have found many small, delicate and anemic children who should be in a sanitary class-room, the three general essentials of which should be;(1) plenty of fresh air; (2) sufficient amount of light; (3) direct sunlight for a part of each day; all of which I have found lacking in these two class-rooms. For the sake of the health of these delicate Indian children and their teachers, I would suggest that the Department take immediate steps to improve these unsatisfactory conditions."

In referring to Departmental File No. 50-5-4 and my letter of this day, you will find attached the original of that report of Doctor Jacobs.

I wish to add that I am informed by the Superior of the Caughnawaga Schools that one of the teachers who was teaching in these two class-rooms at the Kateri School is ill and that her illness is due to draughts circulating constantly and which are caused by the bad location of the partitions.

Monsieur,

Je prends la liberté de vous référer à ma lettre du 25 août dernier relativement à l'état actuel du canal d'égout à l'école Senior, Caughnawaga, et de vous informer que l'extrémité du tuyau en fer qui se prolongeait auparavant au-dessous du niveau de l'eau du fleuve est, à cause de l'eau très basse de la rivière, maintenant complètement à sec. Ceci nous permet de constater que l'eau et les déchets, qui s'échappent parfois en quantité considérable de diverses sources à l'école Senior ne parvient pas du tout à cette extrémité sur le bord du fleuve. Le gardien Robert est descendu dans les buissons et il a constaté que seul un léger filet d'eau claire y passe.

Nous croyons que les déchets s'accumulent à un point où le tuyau de renvoi fait un angle d'environ 45° sur le bord de la rivière. Cet angle est maintenant sous un gros amas de terre, pierres et déchets de toutes sortes qui y ont été transportés par les Indiens du village durant ces deux dernières années. Peut-être que le poids de cette masse de déchets a fait disjoindre le tuyau à son angle et qu'ainsi les déchets ne peuvent parvenir jusqu'à l'extrémité.

Afin de prévenir des dégâts qui pourraient être considérables dans le cours de l'hiver et du printemps prochains, permettez-moi de suggérer que l'Ingénieur du Département vienne à Caughnawaga pour faire l'examen de ce tuyau et remédier, s'il y a lieu, aux dommages qu'il aurait subi.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Agent des Indiens,

Le Secrétaire,
Département des Affaires des Indiens,
OTTAWA.
Sir:

I take the liberty to refer to my letter of the 25 August last concerning the present state of the sewer-pipe of the Senior School, Caughnawaga, and to inform you that the extremity of the iron pipe which was previously laid under the water surface in the river is now on account of the low level of the river is now completely dry. This permitted us to notice that the water and the waste which is sometimes flown in considerable quantity from diverse sources at the Senior School do not reach the extremity of the pipe on the river's edge. The guardian, Robert, went down into the septic tank and found that only a light water jet was passing through.

We believe that the rubbish is accumulating at a point where the sewer-pipe makes an angle of about 45 degrees on the edge of the river. That angle is now under a pile of land, stones and rubbish of all kinds which were thrown there by the Indians of the village during the last two years. It may be that the weight of that rubbish has made the pipe disjointed at that angle and that the waste can not reach the extremity of the pipe.

So as to prevent any damages which might be considerable during the course of the Winter and of next Spring, permit me to suggest that the Engineer of the Department come to Caughnawaga to examine this pipe and find a way to repair it and prevent any further damage.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Lorenzo Letourneau,
Indian Agent.

Subject:- 5-1-5.

Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter of Dec. 22nd., we beg to advise that the Sterilizing System was installed the week of Nov. 7th. We sent a man the next week to sterilize the System, and start the Plant, giving the janitor verbal instructions regarding its operation. The next week we again sent a man over to the Reservation, as Mr. Letourneau asked us to check and make sure that the janitor understood the operation of the Plant. At this time our man brought back a sample of water, and left six bottles with the janitor, who has subsequently submitted two samples. Our bacteriologist reports fermentation in one test out of five in the first sample; and the other two samples - no fermentation developed out of five tests on each sample. Under the microscope, what is known as pin point colonies, were plentiful. These colonies have no sanitary significance, as they signify the presence of a harmless bacteria, which often develops rapidly in sterilized water, due to the absence of natural enemies. The development of this bacteria is also encouraged in samples which are not analyzed immediately.

We are holding our billing until we can supply the School with written instructions in both French and English. These are now in the hands of the Printer. As soon as the instructions
are ready we will again send a representative to the Reservation to deliver these instructions, and to take a sample of both the raw and sterilized water. A third sample of sterilized water will be delivered to the Provincial Board of Health with a request that they send you an independent report on the condition of the water.

Yours very truly,

(a) As to the two trips to St. Isidore Jct. for stove for Bush School, I must say that I was not aware that Albany Robert had charged $5.00 since he was using our horse and express. (b) Oct. 17. Two trips to Station were unavoidable.

(c) Oct. 23rd and Dec. 21st. Evidently, some Officials of the Department have not had the opportunity to visit the Bush School. After leaving the main road, the rest of the way to the school is so difficult to cover, that people prefer walking two miles on the R.R. track in order to avoid marshes, ditches, besides the awful jolting right along. Since cars could not pull thro without meeting accidents after mid September, it was impossible to drive there in our carriage. Even our express wagon broke down when Albany Robert went there to make repairs.

Four years ago, Sr. M. Rose Alma refused to accept the supervision of that school for the same reason as stated above, unless the Department
paid her $10.00 for each visitation.

To speak truthfully, I would willingly relinquish the direction of Bush School because it means such a strain each time.

(d) Voucher A. Jolicoeur, for $5.17 was paid, but omitted by error in the statement.

Caughnawaga, January 19th., 1832.

Secretary of Indian Department,
Booth Building, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Last year, we were favored by the Department with a grant of $100 for the upkeep of our skating-rink. This grant represented the entrance-fee of the school-children who were thus able to have the skating-rink for a few hours every day. Would it be possible for the Department to renew this bounty again this year? The favor would be greatly appreciated as at present our Indians here are very low—more than ever before, it seems—in their amusement-money. Several local attractions, customary to the season, have had to be suppressed already for lack of sufficient monetary support. The expenses of the skating-rink (caretaker's salary, electricity for power and light, help for clearing of snow, etc.) run too high and the receipts of an occasional hockey-game too low for the proposition to be self-supporting. A grant such as that of last year would solve the problem.

I take occasion of this letter to extend to the Department sincere thanks and congratulations for the splendid work done by Miss Moody among our women-folk. These persons are a difficult and sometimes rather annoying class to deal with on account of their inbred shyness wherever strangers are concerned. Miss Moody by her tact and pleasant disposition has won them over. She has been very busy here straightening out the countless wants of the ladies here. I am sure her good advice will help them a great deal.

I beg to remain, Sir,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 26, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, requesting a grant of $100 towards the upkeep of the community rink in the village of Caughnawaga.

In this connection I have to inform you that our grant last year was not towards the upkeep of the rink, but was to pay for 125 sheets of corrugated iron, used for the sides of the rink. It was promised, in view of the above payment by this Department, that the school children would be given free skating up to 6 P.M. daily, with the exception of school hours. The Department understood that this concession to school children was of a more or less permanent nature because of our assistance when the rink was first prepared. At no time was a grant for current expenses discussed. As our appropriation at the present time is extremely limited, I regret that favourable consideration cannot be given to your request.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Comme le travail était pas ordinaire sur la réparation de la classe c'est pour la raison que j'ai chargé cela.

Ainsi le transport de l'eau pour l'école dernière nuit a causé que le système pour mettre l'eau potable pour bois était pas installé et pourquoi que j'ai chargé ce prix, ainsi de plus le chauffeur que j'ai transporté de l'école Katine pour l'école dernière.

Comme le travail de réparation était fini en sept du foire j'ai donc laissé le travail de la cour de l'école, mais je ne peux pas dire si tout est fait ou non, donc je peux y retourner dans jour ou même $100 par voyage.

Nov. 30
Quelques mots au sujet du nettoyage de la grande salle de l'école de Rivière-du-Loup. Elle est trop froide pour cause que le vent souffle après la réunion des écoles protestantes qui se tient à Rivière-du-Loup. Nous devons faire quelque chose pour le bien-être de nos enfants.
Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant concerning the account of Albany Robert, amounting to $125.45 and in reply to inform you that there is no grass cutter at that school to cut the hay and bad weeds on the playing ground of senior school and Robert thought of renting that horse drawn mower which I believe was more economical than to pay a man by the day to do the work with a hand scythe. Robert is going to produce a receipt for that sum of $3.00.

September 19 - We admit that it is the duty of the two guardians at the United Church School to do the washing and install the double windows at the school. But they neglect and refused to do so and that is why I am forced to have recourse to the services of Robert. The present guardians or others of Caughnawaga who would be called to replace them generally have a great repulsion of water and of the broom and they neglected or refused to do any small repairs.

Sept. 30 & Oct. 2: - In referring to your letter of the 19th September last (File No. 5-3-8) you authorized me to make the purchase of a stove for the Bush School. The shipper assured me then that that stove would be at the station at St. Isidore Junction at a set date; I had then requested Robert to go and get it, a distance of eight miles return. The Agent at the station replied to Robert that the stove had not arrived. From Caughnawaga Robert afterwards telephoned to inform me of this incident and after several inquiries I was finally informed that the stove was at its destination on the day mentioned but the conductor of the train had forgotten or neglected to hand the way bill to the Agent of the station. That is the reason why Robert had to make a second trip to St. Isidore Junction, that is to say two trips 16 miles and transportation to Bush School six more miles total 22 miles apart from the installation of the stove and I think that his charges of $3.00 is just and reasonable.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Oct. 31 - As I explained above, the floors of the United Church Schools become so dirty on account of the negligence of the Indians that Miss Simons has requested Robert to attend to it. I believe again that $5.00 to clean and oil this floor is an acceptable charge. I often asked the teachers of the United Church Schools to inform me if they wanted the guardians to be replaced. I believe that if they do not ask for any change it is most likely that they believe, as I do, that to replace these Indians by two others would not improve the situation at all.

Nov. 7 - Kateri School. I did not ask Robert to do the cleaning of the class rooms after the changes were completed at the Kateri School, however, I knew that this cleaning was not of an ordinary nature after this work was completed; removal of rubbish etc.; he told me that he thought that that extra work deserved a compensation.

If you will kindly refer to your letter of the 15th September last you will find that Robert obliged to carry from four to six pails of drinking water every school day, from the opening of the school until the 15th of November.

November 30 - If you will kindly refer to your letter No. 5-1-1 dated December 11 last, arrangements were made to permit the children of the United Church Schools to have their Christmas Concert in the hall of the Senior School. After that concert the floors and stairs were left absolutely dirty. It seems evident that this cleaning does not come under the regular work of the guardian of the Senior School.

I can assure you that I have no favour to do to Albany Robert but I have often noticed that he is a good servant, very conscientious, laborious and careful. When I find that repairs, cleaning, etc., become absolutely necessary at both of the United Church Schools I have no other way than to obtain the services of Robert to do the work. As the toilet became unapproachable, that the floors of the schools are dirty, that the glasses in the doors and windows are broken and the guardians in charge neglect to fulfill their duties, should I then advise you each time for every case? This would be very annoying to you, or is it not as I believe preferable to have recourse immediately to the services of an employee who, I am sure only asks in return a just and reasonable supplementary salary.

I have, however, recently warned Robert, not to do any work at the United Church Schools nor to lend any tools to the guardians of the schools unless he is sure that they will be brought back and that until you find it proper to advise me to the contrary.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Lorenzo Letourneau,
Indian Agent.
Monsieur,

J'ai l'honneur d'accuser réception de votre lettre du 13 courant concernant le compte de Albany Robert au montant de $123.45 et en réponse de vous informer qu'il n'y a pas de faucheuse à cette école pour couper le foin et mauvaises herbes sur le terrain de jeux à l'école Senior et Robert a cru devoir louer cette faucheuse à chevaux ce qui, je crois, était plus économique que de payer un homme à la journée pour le faire avec une faucille à mains. Robert doit produire un reçu pour cette somme de $3.00.

Sept. 19 - Nous admettons qu'il est du devoir des deux gardiens aux écoles United Church de faire le lavage et installer les châssis doubles à ces écoles, mais ils négligent et finalement refusent de le faire et c'est ainsi que je me vois dans l'obligation de recourir aux services de Robert. Les gardiens actuels ou d'autres de Caughnawaga qui seraient appelés à les remplacer ont généralement horreur de l'eau et du balai et ils négligent ou refusent de faire quelques légères réparations.

Sept. 30 & Oct. 2. - En répondant à votre lettre du 19 septembre dernier (F. 5-3-8) vous m'autorisez à faire l'achat d'un poêle pour l'école Bush. L'expéditeur m'a alors assuré que ce poêle serait rendu à la gare St.Isidore-junction à un jour indiqué; j'avais alors requis Robert d'aller le chercher, une distance de 5 miles aller et retour. L'agent de la gare a répondu à Robert que ce poêle n'était pas arrivé. De Caughnawaga Robert m'a ensuite téléphoné pour m'informer de la chose et après beaucoup de démarches j'ai été finalement informé que ce poêle était à destination au jour indiqué mais que le conducteur du train avait oublié ou négligé de remettre le connaissment à l'agent de gare. C'est pour cette raison que Robert a fait un deuxième voyage à St.Isidore-junction, ainsi, deux voyages, 16 miles et transport à l'école Bush 6 autres miles, total 22 miles à part l'installation de ce poêle, je crois que $3.00 est juste et raisonnable.

Le Secrétaire,
Département des Affaires Indiennes,
OTTAWA.
Oct. 31 -

Comme je vous l'ai expliqué plus haut, les planchers des écoles United Church deviennent tellement sales à cause de la négligence des gardiens que Miss Simons a demandé Robert d'y voir. Je crois encore que $5.00 pour laver et huiler ce plancher est acceptable. J'ai souvent demandé aux institutrices des écoles United Church de m'informer si elles désirent que les gardiens soient remplacés. Je crois que si elles ne demandent pas ce changement c'est que peut-être comme moi elles croient que remplacer ces deux Indiens par deux autres Indiens n'améliorerait pas cette situation.

Novembre 7 - École Kateri. Je n'ai pas demandé à Robert de faire le nettoyage des classes après que les modifications furent terminées à l'école Kateri, cependant, je sais que ce n'était pas un nettoyage ordinaire à faire après ces travaux; transport des déchets, etc.; il me dit qu'il croit que ce travail supplémentaire mériterait compensation.

Si vous voulez bien référer à votre lettre du 15 septembre dernier vous constaterez que Robert était dans l'obligation de charroyer quatre à six chaudières d'eau potable, chaque jour scolaire, depuis l'ouverture des classes jusqu'au 15 du mois de novembre.

30 Novembre. - Si vous voulez bien référer à votre lettre N°. 5-1-1 en date du 11 décembre dernier, des arrangements ont été faits pour permettre aux enfants des écoles United Church d'avoir leur concert de Noël dans la salle de l'école Senior. Après ce concert les planchers et les escaliers ont été laissés dans un état de malpropreté, il semble évident que ce nettoyage n'entre pas dans le travail régulier du gardien de l'école Senior.

Je puis vous assurer que je n'ai pas de faveurs à faire à Albany Robert, mais j'ai souvent constaté qu'il est un bon serviteur, très conciencieux, travaillant et parcimonieux. Lorsque je constate que des réparations, nettoyage, etc., deviennent absolument nécessaires aux deux écoles United Church il ne me reste pas d'autres alternatives que de recourir aux services de Robert. Parce que les cabinets d'aisance deviennent inabordables, que les planchers des écoles sont sales, que les vitres des portes et fenêtres sont brisées et que les gardiens nommés négligent de remplir leur devoir, dois-je alors vous en aviser dans chaque cas ?, ce serait ennuyeux pour vous, ou,
ou, comme je le crois, n'est-il pas plutôt préférable de recourir immédiatement aux services d'un employé qui, je le sais, n'exige en retour qu'un salaire supplémentaire juste et raisonnable.

J'ai cependant récemment averti Robert de ne plus faire aucun travail aux écoles United Church, ni de prêter des outils, etc., aux gardiens de ces écoles à moins qu'il ait la certitude que ce lui serait rapporté, cela, jusqu'à ce que vous auriez à propos de m'aviser du contraire.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

[Signature]

Agent des Indiens.
Ottawa, January 30, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, concerning the account of Albany Robert to the amount of $125.45 for repairs, cleaning, materials purchased and other incidental expenses in connection with the schools, your office and jail on the Osughnawaga Reserve. In this connection I have to say that, in view of your explanation regarding a number of items in the account, the Department has decided to allow payment in full, and a cheque will be forwarded in due course.

In connection with the janitors' services at the schools on the Gaughnawaga Reserve, it is felt that if all the janitors carried out their duties it should not be necessary to call upon Mr. Robert to perform the extra work as charged for by him in the account above referred to. I would point out that the Department expects Matthew Lazare and F. K. Diabo to carry out the following duties, viz.: light the fires and have the classrooms warm before the children arrive each school day; sweep the classrooms; put on and take off double windows and wash and clean same; any snow shovelling required and any other duties which they are called upon to perform by yourself and the teachers. You should inform both these janitors of the duties they are expected to perform and also advise the teachers. The Department also feels that for the salary paid Albany Robert, Joseph Geitens and Mrs. Geitens they should perform all the duties required of them by the Reverend Sisters and yourself at the R. C. Schools and teachers' residence.

With all the caretakers doing their duty, it should only be necessary, in future, for Mr. Robert to perform very few services for which he will expect extra pay. Therefore, in future, all work, such as cleaning and installing windows; scrubbing and cleaning classrooms; moving desks, etc., and keeping the grounds in good condition, should form part of the regular duties of the janitors. You should see each of the janitors named above at an early date and explain to them fully the work the Department expects them to perform for the salary they are being paid.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Monsieur,

Je soumets respectueusement sous ce pli un compte au montant de $10.90 qui est produit aux Revdes. Soeurs enseignantes à Caughnawaga par la Compagnie Nu-Way Oil Burner, Montréal, pour des réparations qui ont été faites au bruleur à l'huile de l'école Senior et je ne crois pas pouvoir recommander ce compte pour approbation par le Département avant que de vous donner les explications suivantes.

Le gardien des écoles a en premier lieu téléphoné à la Compagnie Nu-Way les informant que le bruleur ne fonctionnait pas et leur a suggéré de venir y faire les réparations nécessaires. Cependant Robert informait en même temps la Compagnie qu'entre-temps il ferait son possible afin de localiser le trouble. À cela la Compagnie Nu-Way a répondu à Robert de n'y rien faire. Malgré cela Robert s'est immédiatement mis à l'oeuvre et il prétend avoir réussi à localiser le défaut puisque le bruleur s'est ensuite mis à fonctionner. Alors Robert a téléphoné de nouveau à la Compagnie pour leur dire de ne pas venir à Caughnawaga mais on lui a répondu que deux de leurs employés étaient déjà partis pour la réserve. En effet ces deux hommes se sont rendus à l'école Senior, mais ils n'avaient rien à remédier puisque le bruleur fonctionnait normalement.

Je crois devoir laisser cette question à votre considération en vous priant de m'informer s'il y a lieu pour moi de remplir les formalités habituelles pour la production de ce compte au Département.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Agent des Indiens.

Sir:

I respectfully submit, enclosed herewith, an account amounting to $10.90, which was sent to the Rev. Sisters teaching at Caughnawaga, by the Nu-Way Oil Burner Company, Montreal, for repairs which were done to the oil burner of the Senior school and I do not believe I should recommend this account to the approval of the Department before giving the following explanations.

The caretaker of the school first telephoned to the Nu-Way Company to inform them that the burner was not working properly and suggested that they should come to do the necessary repairs. However, Robert informed at the same time the Company that in the meantime he would do his best to locate the trouble. To that the Nu-Way Company replied to Robert not to touch it. However, Robert immediately started to work and he states that he succeeded in locating the defect, since the burner started to work immediately. Then Robert telephoned again to the Company to tell them not to come to Caughnawaga but they replied that two of their men had already left for the reserve. In fact these two men went to the Senior School, but there was nothing for them to do as the burner was working normally.

I believe I should leave this matter for your consideration and I wish you would kindly inform me if you desire me to follow the usual formalities to produce the account to the Department.

Pour le plancher de l'école (je ne peux pas lire le nom de l'école), je dis que nous avons été obligés de faire les travaux de nos écoles.

Pour l'école St. Bridget Road ou n'est pas seulement que l'installation de l'échelle, c'est aussi pour avoir refait le toit de la résidence.

Maintenant, pour le changement des fournitures à 2 ou 3 écoles, Burkh dit moi formellement qu'il aurait fait tout ses voyages et réparations pour nous aider dans la préparation en faire acheter des nouvelles.

Pour le bâtiment carré par Mr. Seguin de St. Boniface, il était de toute justice qu'il le fasse réparer, mais comme nous en avions abondamment besoin, la Réserve nous refuse la facture.

Ensuite, pour le prix de $10.00 toilette, école St. Bridget Road ou est le même prix des années passées et ce prix aura été pris à mon engagement.
Quand j'ai été nommé gardien des écoles de gouvernement indiens, je ne savais pas que je devais faire.

Maintenant, pour le bois, il faut le donner à différents endroits : écoles, maisons, officiers, etc., quand on me fait arriver ce bois, on me dit qu'il doit être livré au bois au jour et à mesure que je m'en approche. Il est de toute justice que je ne peux pas obliger de faire tout les travaux pour les écoles ou les professeurs, car je ne peux pas.

Au sujet du nettoyage de la prison et des alentours après la distribution des grains de semences, comme le chef avait été fait d'ordre d'avant, j'ai eu bien soin en le faisant dans les mêmes conditions.

Maintenant, comme je déteste les malentendus, et vous rien avoir que j'ai pas gagné, malgré que mon salaire est pas insuffisant, même avant de m'avoir relevé 10/100 je suis encore prêt à faire et ferai, si vous trouvez que la chose est juste.

Cependant, M. Robert désire que vous lui permettiez de vous donner connaissance des raisons pour lesquelles il a cru que le compte original de $119.20 était juste et raisonnable. Sa lettre du 12 courant est attachée à la présente.

Je profite de cette occasion pour vous soumettre respectueusement que la fournaise de l'école Bush est maintenant hors de service. Dans le cours de l'hiver dernier M. Robert a fait plusieurs voyages à cette école pour la repérer, quoiqu'il n'y fut pas tenu, et il l'a ensuite échangée pour la fournaise de la prison afin de ne pas priver l'école Bush de ses jours de classes. La fournaise de la prison a été remise en assez bon état par M. Robert, mais celle de l'école Bush devra être remplacée avant l'ouverture des classes. Je vous prie de bien vouloir m'autoriser à faire l'achat d'une fournaise au coût approximatif de $25.00. Je désire ajouter que le charbon "coke", en usage depuis l'hiver dernier dans les écoles de la réserve, est de nature à faire déteriorer plus rapidement les fournaises.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Le Secrétaire,
Agent des Indiens,

Ottawa, January 11, 1934.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your voucher No. 3881 for $53.15, covering the cost of urgent repairs to the water system, etc., in the teachers' residence on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

No authority was given for this expenditure, and, before payment can be considered, the Department wishes a full report stating why it was necessary to incur this expenditure without first obtaining the Department's authority.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant,
P.Q.
Dear Mr. Agent,

In reply to your letter of Jan. 13, 1934, asking for further information concerning voucher #3851 for $25.15 worth of repairs in the Teachers' Residence, I wish to state that no one voluntarily had the intention of incurring expenses without the Department's authority. Where permission had not been previously obtained, the repairs were emergency cases.

The most striking item on the bill was the renewal of the kitchen hot water tank which had suddenly run a very heavy leak. The plumbers took down the tank for a closer examination and found it not only useless to patch up the opening but dangerous to set the tank again as the zinc was so corroded by the hard water and similar leaks were liable to break out at any time. Hence when I mentioned the matter to you, Mr. Letourneau, you secured the permission authorizing the installation of the new tank.

While the plumbers were in the house, I was asked if a leak in the toilet-room could not also be attended to as it was impossible to cram in a pail under the box to receive the dripping water. The plumber found that this small tank also had been corroded by hard water beyond repair. He brought it off with him immediately as during this season, when boats are not running, he avoids as many trips as possible with his truck over the Victoria Bridge, about a 30 mile trip out of the way. Whenever the material required for repairs is not too heavy, and he can make suitable connections with the trains, in such a way as not to lose too much time, he gladly does so.

The trouble in the Teachers' Residence was not at an end. This time the hard water again caused the pipes in the kitchen stove to burst. A new water-front had to be put in without delay so as not to deprive the teachers of their hot meals.

Then the interior of the oil-burner called for new bricks, the others being worn out to the iron. As the furnace was in a condition to cause serious and imminent damage, I spoke to you about it, Mr. Letourneau and your reply was that this was an emergency case----to have the furnace attended to at once. Hence two men worked at it half a day and at the same time renewed the pipe of the small coal furnace which is heated only when the electricity gives out and the oil-burner cannot be used. The large holes found in this pipe were mostly caused by rust. While the men were at their work, I asked them to tell me what was wrong with the electric water-pump. The trouble was found to be connected with the safety-valve. A new one was put on, but I still have the old one on hand and shall have it repaired if possible.
About the worst annoyance arose in the bathroom which became suddenly invaded with a terrible stench. Moreover, in the bath tub fecal matter even came up the drain pipe from the toilet next door. The odor was so strong and the sleeping rooms so close-by that there was every chance of the Sisters becoming victims to typhoid fever, and it was too cold to open the windows. Knowing that no Health Department allows delay in such matters, we had the plumber try to locate the cause of the trouble. After repeated efforts and a great deal of difficulty and trying labor, he discovered that a hard, strong mass had formed in the air-pipe connected with the drain pipe and had blocked circulation.

This, dear Mr. Letourneau is a summary of the unpleasant and manifold disturbances the teachers enjoyed during their Christmas holidays.

I trust that the Department will not find that I have acted unwisely and tried to take the general management of things in my own hands. I did all for the best, thinking the Department would be the first to encourage me to have these urgent repairs attended to in time.

Hoping I have given you satisfactory explanations, dear Mr. Letourneau,

I am

Your humble servant

Caretaker

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF A. E. WESCOTT,
SEPARATE SCHOOL INSPECTOR, Apt. 26, 4710 Decarie Boulevard, Montreal, Que., dated May 26, 1934.

Original on 5-1-6.

CAUGHNAWAGA INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS (inspected between April 25 & May 11)

Condition of Buildings: I have already remarked, in the particular reports of the Eastern and Kateri Schools, that the upper floor classrooms of these schools are poorly lighted. In some of these rooms, the situation is made worse by the fact that some of this insufficient light comes from the wall facing the pupils. This can be remedied, to a certain extent, in the room that is occupied by the girls of the 2nd Grade, in the Kateri School, by arranging the desks to face in the opposite direction. If the roofs of these schools were raised, it would be possible to remedy this situation, without the addition of any new floor-space.

In the report on the Senior School, you will find remarks on the condition of the paint on the interior walls of that school and on the advisability of certain improvements in the boys' lavatory.
EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF SEPARATE SCHOOL
INSPECTOR A. E. WESCOTT, on his visit to
SENIOR SCHOOL on Caughnawaga Reserve, inspected
MAY 7, 8, 9 & 11, 1934.

Original on 5-1-6.

1. Unfortunately, there must have been some essential ingredient lacking in the paint used on the interior walls, as the paint is falling off the walls, in large flakes or scales, in many parts of the building.

2. In the boys' lavatory, there are only two urinals for the use of forty-three boys. As a consequence, the other toilet-bowls are often used as urinals. I would respectfully suggest the addition of two new urinals, for sanitary reasons. There is ample room for this addition.

When in Caughnawage last week my attention was brought to the condition of the window openings at the Central School. I noted that the wood window sills had openings outside through which water seeps into the exterior walls. I would suggest that these cracks or openings be filled with plastic weather stripping, similar to that used for the weather-proofing of the window frames.

There is also a door sill which is entirely rotted away. If there are funds available I would recommend that this work be attended to as soon as possible.

I would also suggest that provision be made for the painting of the exterior wood and metal work early next spring, that is the fire escapes, oil tank, steel fences, etc.

Departmental Engineer.
August 28, 1934.

Dear Sir,

The Department is advised that the wooden window sills of the Central School at Caughnawaga are in need of repairs, consisting in the filling of cracks on the outside.

It is suggested that these cracks be filled with plastic weather stripping, similar to that used for the weather-proofing of the window frames.

There is also a door sill which should be replaced, and I would ask you to arrange with the caretaker of the building to attend to this work as early as possible. The plaster cement, etc., may be purchased from a dealer on your approved list. Window sills only may be painted after they have been repaired.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

L. Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant, Que.

Sir:

I would kindly ask you to authorize the expenditure of $12.00 towards the extending of the discharge pipe of the sewerage system of the Caughnawaga Senior School and also to cover same with either gravel or large stones.

This pipe had been extended in the river two or three years ago but owing to the low level of the St. Lawrence river at present it will be necessary to buy an additional 10 feet of pipe of 6 inches as the actual pipe does not reach the river and is uncovered. If the pipe remains in its actual state there will be a danger of damaging the system by the frost during the ensuing winter, which would cost more to repair than the extending of the pipe.

It has been figured that the cost of the pipe would amount to $8.00 and $4.00 for the labour.

Your obedient servant

(Frs. Brisebois)

Caughnawaga, December 20, 1934.

Sir:

You will find herewith voucher No. 111 amounting to $25.00 and in favour of Mr. Bruno Pilon, Plumber, for repairs made and material supplied at the Sisters' Residence and at the Caughnawaga Village Schools.

I beg to point out that the repairs etc., have been made by Mr. Pilon at the request of Rev. Sister Superior and of Mr. Robert Janitor. As I am at Caughnawaga every day of the week I wish to say that, if I am to be held responsible for all the expenses made I would like to be consulted, either by the Sister Superior or the Janitor, in order to secure proper authorization from the Department and also to find out if the expenses are really needed.

In connection with the enclose account I have to let you know that I did not know anything about it until I received same. Previous to the 1st of October last, my predecessor was coming to the Reserve twice a week, on Tuesday and Friday and from 2 to 4 pm, and as he was living at 12 miles from Caughnawaga, he had instructed the Sisters and Mr. Robert to have any necessary repairs made without consulting him. But as I am here 5 days a week presently and will be at the Agency 6 days weekly after the 1st of January next I would recommend that no exception be made for the local Schools or the Sister's Residence with regard to expenses.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, December 26, 1934.

Madam:

Mr. Agent Brisebois has forwarded a voucher for $25.00, covering the cost of material and repairs at the Rev. Sisters' residence, Caughnawaga.

It would appear that the repairs were made by Mr. Pilon, at your request, without consulting the Agent in the matter. I should be very pleased if, in future, before undertaking any repairs to the residences or schools under your charge, or in the purchase of any supplies, you would make your request through the office of Mr. Agent Brisebois. As Mr. Brisebois is present on the reserve each day, there should be little trouble occasioned to you in consulting him. It is necessary that he refer all requests to the Department and receive authority before undertaking any repairs or purchasing any supplies. It is expected that the janitor of the schools, Mr. Robert, will also consult the Indian Agent before he authorizes any work being done. Since the new Agent has been appointed, it is required that his recommendation accompany all requests for repairs, equipment and supplies of all kinds. I am sure you will be pleased to comply with the Department's requirements.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I am requested by Rev. Father Menard together with a group of leading Indians of this reserve to submit to your consideration their request for a grant from the Department towards the making and the upkeep of a skating rink. The promoters of the rink are claiming that the Indians of Caughnawaga are presently very poor and consequently are unable to meet with all the expenses involved for a rink, they claim that with a small help from the Department the population of the Band would be provided with good distraction. It is understood that a grant from the Department would be to entitle all the children of the Caughnawaga Schools to skate every day of the week after school and all day on Saturday. It was represented that the young men are presently without any place to go and that they are hanging around pool rooms and other places where it would be better for them not to go. It is claimed that a rink would gather the youth and that responsible persons would maintain the good order.

Although I am aware that the Department has more serious things to consider and that expenses are very heavy for relief etc., I beg to say that any amount given, be it very small, would be very much appreciated. It is also considered that any village or small town having the same population as Caughnawaga, has its own skating rink, which provides distractions for the old and young, and that if a certain sum is granted it should be on the ground to provide amusement for schoolchildren.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Caughnawaga, April 9th, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I beg to let you know that the inside and outside of the Caughnawaga R.C. Senior School is badly in need of repairs. This school has not been repaired since its building. The repairs would consist in repairing the brick joints of the outside walls of the school and also the fence brick posts of the main entrance leading to the school. The work to be done inside would consist in the painting of the walls, on which the paint is coming off by spots.

For further details or informations, relative to the state of repairs of the above school, I would kindly refer you to Mr. Chene, Engineer of your Department, who visited same on Thursday 4th instant, when at Caughnawaga.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Sutherland,

I visited the Caughnawaga Reserve on the third instant and, in company with Mr. Agent Brisebois, I carefully inspected the Senior School.

The paint on the walls of the interior of each room is curled and, in order to keep the building in good condition, it is advisable to remove this old paint and repaint the interior walls of each classroom.

Mr. Brisebois obtained two quotations for this work, which are attached:

(1) S. Jolicoeur offers to do the work for $275.00.

(2) Louis Saylor - an Indian - offers to do the work for $221.00.

Mr. Brisebois stated that he considered that Mr. Jolicoeur would handle the work in a better manner than Saylor. In the event of Jolicoeur being given the job, he will employ Saylor to do some work.

The above-mentioned interior painting is very necessary and I would strongly recommend that it be done during the coming summer holidays.

In addition to the interior painting, the oil tank at the back of the building should also be painted in order to keep it from rusting.

I do not consider that it is necessary to incur any expenditure this year for painting the exterior of the window frames and the fire escapes. The painting of these can be postponed until next year.

Caughnawaga, August 14, 1935.

Sir:

I beg to transmit you herewith the list of repairs needed at the different schools of Caughnawaga, which should be made, if possible, before the opening of the classes.

Bush School.

The repairs at that school would consist in the building of a new fence for the school yard. The present fence is now out of order and the animals have access to the school yard, just as if there was no fence at all. There are 66 fence posts in all for this fence, out of this number, 31 could be utilised leaving 35 to be replaced by new ones, 600 ft. of fence wire 4 ft. high and about 15 lbs of staples would also have to be bought. The price for the posts is of $0.12 each (4 inches) the price of the fencing wire is $0.18 a yard (4 ft. high) and $0.07 a lb. for the staples. The total material required would amount to approximately, $42.00. If recommended, I would suggest that the work be done free of charge by the chief janitor Albany Robert, his assistant Jos. Cassien and the janitor of this school Michael O. Phillips. Enclosed herewith is a letter from the teacher, pertaining to the fence.

St-Isidore School.

The only repairs required at this school are for the window screens which are in bad order, the frames of the screens are good; the wire netting only, has to be replaced. 15 yards of screen would be needed at $0.50 a yard. The work should be done free of charge by Albany Robert, chief janitor.

Protestant School Senior.

No repairs needed.

Protestant School Junior.

The repairs needed at this school consist in the repairing of the front porch which is in bad shape and dangerous for the children. As this building belongs to the United Church and is only rented by the Department, I would kindly ask you to communicate with the authorities of the Church, in order that the necessary repairs be made.
Kateri School.

Several radiator valves of the heating system of this school are broken. This should be repaired before the cold weather comes. The janitor in charge also requested that 2 dozens of window blinds be supplied, as the ones in use are a little too short. This is not recommended as they are considered good enough for at least another year.

Eastern School.

Several radiator valves are broken and also the sump of a sink. The pipe from the school to the well is broken and the pipe inside the well is thought to have dropped down the well when an attempt to repair it was made last Spring by the janitor. If this pipe cannot be reached, a new one will be needed at an approximate cost of $10. for the pipe only. The cost of labour for a plumber, for the repairing of the valves and also the piping system of the well is estimated at about $20. The digging of the trench from the school to the well should be made free of charge by the janitor and his assistant. In addition to these repairs, the three revolving gates which are now broken, should be repaired at an approximate cost of $5.00 for the three. The roof of the toilets at this school will have to be renewed. In the course of April, an authorization for shingles, from the Department, in order to repair this same roof was received. The shingles were bought but not utilized as it was found out that the boards of the roof were rotten. The entire boards of the roof have to be removed and covered anew with shingles. This roof measures 16 X 32 ft. and the renewing of the roof is estimated at about $40. for material. The work should be made in this case also by the janitor and his assistant. Two dozens of window blinds were also requested for this school, but are not considered urgently needed.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, regarding the painting of the interior walls of the Senior School of this Reserve and informing me that the quotation of S. Jolicoeur, Lachine, Que., was accepted for the repairing and re-touching of the walls and the painting - one coat - for the sum of $275.

In reply, I beg to say that the work is now carried on by the contractor who is employing Louis Sayler, Indian of this Reserve.

However, I beg to inform you that owing to the conditions of the walls and due to the peeling off of the old paint and the repairs made, one coat of paint is not sufficient and is far from making a satisfactory work. Due to the small cracks in the walls, one coat of paint penetrates so that it leaves marks or spots almost everywhere. In order to see the difference between one coat and two coats, the contractor painted one room with two coats and I have to say that with two coats, no marks are showing and thus making a first class job. As the contractor is not yet through with the first coat and is still at the Senior School, with his men, I would recommend that a second coat of paint on the walls be authorized. Mr. Jolicoeur would be ready to undertake the painting of an additional coat for the sum of $90. I would kindly ask you to let me know as soon as possible if this recommendation is accepted, in order that the contractor be advised before he resumes work.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant with reference to the accounts from the Shewinigan Water & Power Company and in which you requested to be informed of the manner in which the Company is preparing its accounts, in order to render possible the proper computing of the amount due.

In reply, I beg to say that after having interviewed the "Manager Commercial And Distribution Department" of the Company, the following explanations have been secured.

1. The rate for the Senior School is the one charged for all public buildings, stores, etc., where rate 190 is not applicable because this rate is for domestic use only. The Company is considering the teachers' residence as a private residence and is therefore computing the account on rate 190, which is cheaper than 192. It is preferable that the rate in use at the residence remains as it is.

2. Relative to the account for electricity at the Senior School, I beg to inform you that the appearance of two meter readings on the same account is due to the fact that the old meter was changed about the middle of the month, therefore showing a reading for this regular meter as follows: present reading, 1222, previous reading, 1174 giving a consumption of 48 kwhrs. The new meter, of a type called Lincoln E.D. Demand Meter showing a reading as follows: present reading, .0015, previous reading, .0004, giving a consumption of 11 kws. I beg to point out that this new meter, which will be in use in the future, is a type of meter registering only 1/5 of the electricity consumed, therefrom, the multiplying of the number of kilowatts amperes, by 5. The amount of electricity used at the Senior School for the month of November is, on the old meter, of 48 kwhrs. and of 11 kws.X 5 or 55 kws., on the new meter, for a total of 103 kwhrs.
You will find enclosed, as requested, the electricity accounts for November, but you will notice that the account for the Senior School has been corrected after a communication was received, on the 16th instant, from the Shawinigan Water & Power Company at Valleyfield, enclosing a corrected statement of the account.

I would kindly ask you to cancel Voucher No.847 amounting to $27.84, which will be replaced by Voucher No.847A amounting to $27.34. The reason for this error, according to the Company, is that we were billed on a demand of 4 kw., whereas the demand should have been 2.5 kw. for service charge.

Montreal Que.,
January 28, 1936.

François Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Dear Sir:

No doubt you are aware that a Skating Rink has just been completed on the property adjoining the Parochial Hall. This rink has been realized only after heavy expenses were made, and as it is now, there are a number of payments that will have to be met within the next few weeks. To briefly summarize the work done and things purchased - for which we owe -

(1) The land had to be plowed and levelled and necessitated the hiring of 3 or 4 men with a team of horses.
(2) New wiring and lights had to be installed.
(3) Heat Coal and Food, and many other small items which are too lengthy to enumerate.
(4) Flooding etc.

Up to the present time, during the days, we have been permitting the school boys and girls on the rink for the purposes of skating free of charge, and it is for this reason that we desire to make an appeal to the Department of Indian Affairs for financial aid. The generosity of the Department in matters such as these, has been known in the past, and we are certain that apart from the help that we may derive from any help that may be given us, the school children will benefit morally and physically; it will prevent the children from hanging around pool rooms and from running the streets.

We are certain, and we hope, that the Department will contribute generously - and we are making this sincere and earnest request through your good self.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Harry Williams,
Secretary,
Michael K. Jacobs,
Moderator

Dear Doctor Stone:

Re' Kateri Tekakwitha School (R.C.)

On Oct. 1, 1931, I made a report to you on the unsanitary conditions existing in the class-rooms of the upper floor in the above school. I have complained of these conditions again and again, but nothing has yet been done to correct it. I was informed by the local Indian agent that Mr. Chief of the Department saw these class-rooms a year ago, and at that time he said funds would be voted for this fiscal year to make the necessary structural changes to improve the unsanitary conditions. In another six weeks, classes again will begin, so that there is now not much time to do this necessary work.
There are usually about 50 to 60 small school children in these two class-rooms and they require plenty of fresh air, sufficient amount of light and direct sunlight for a part of each day, but they cannot have that in their class-rooms. No serious structural operation would be required.

It would only be necessary to replace the four windows on the East, South and West sides with small dingy windows, as a matter of fact, four large bay windows. As a matter of fact, I am told that it could be done at a very small cost.

As I have been complaining of the above condition for a long time and as nothing has yet been done, I wish you would persuade the Department to do something for the sake of the health of the young Indian school children now.

Thanking you, I am

Your truly,

L. W. Jacobs M.D.
Ottawa, July 31st, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, addressed to Dr. E. L. Stone.

With reference to your complaint regarding certain rooms in the Kateri School, the Department investigated this matter when you wrote some months' ago and it was decided at that time that, owing to the expense involved, no action could be taken.

In future, you should not correspond direct with the Department regarding such matters, but should discuss them with the Indian Agent, who will report if necessary.

Yours truly,

T. H. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Dr. J. H. Jacobs,
Gaughnawaga,
