Caughnawaga, September 24, 1936.

Dear Sir:

It has been discovered yesterday that the fuel oil tank at the local R.C. Senior School was defective and that about 100 gallons of oil had been lost during the two previous days. Upon being so advised, the fuel distributors, Mongeau & Robert & Co., who are supplying us the fuel oil for this year for Come Lanctot of St. Isidore, who has the contract - were requested to send a truck to empty the tank at once, which was done.

However, the tank will have to be taken out of the ground and thoroughly examined and repaired. I would suggest that the Company's men, who are specialized in such work, be requested to make the repairs needed. It is understood that this account would be charged to Come Lanctot, who would afterwards charge it to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Sept. 26, 1936.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 24th instant with reference to the defective condition of the fuel oil tank in the Central School at Caughnawaga.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange with Come Lanotot of St. Isidore to have this tank taken out and repaired with the least possible delay. It is desired that you personally supervise the work of repairing and installing the tank in order that you may be in a position to verify and certify that the work has been properly carried out. It should be done as economically as possible.

It might also be advisable to arrange to have the tank re-coated with asphalt paint before it is again buried in the ground, after it has been thoroughly tested.

Yours very truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes.
Acting Secretary.

Fr. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Caughnawaga, October 5, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I beg to refer to your letter of the 26th ultimo dealing with the repairs to be done to the oil tank at the Senior School, Caughnawaga and to say that the tank has actually been taken out of the ground and has been found to be pierced by rust at many places, the corroding action of the rust has also attacked the whole part of the tank which was underground. It is claimed that the damage is due to the fact that it was only half buried and that the tank should have been all buried or installed completely on the ground.

It is stated by the officials of the Company making the repairs, for C. Lanctot of St. Isidore, that if this tank is welded only at the several places where it now leaks, we will likely have to start the same work all over again before long, as the rust has damaged it very badly. It has been suggested that a new tank be installed, but instead of being of a capacity of 3000 gallons, as the present one, a tank of approximately 1500 should meet the requirements, as since the construction of the new bridge, oil can be obtained at a few hours' notice the roads being kept open during the winter months.

In view of the actual condition of the tank and the contentions advanced, the price of a new tank was obtained and was found to be as follows: for one of 4" thick, 5' diameter and 13' long of a capacity of approximately 1550 gallons, of $225. taxes included, delivered at Caughnawaga. The excavation now made would be sufficient to receive a new smaller tank, which should all be buried.

However, I would kindly ask you to let me know whether it is your wish that the actual tank be repaired or if you think advisable to have a new one installed.

I would ask you to inform me of your decision as soon as possible, as the school is without fire. For the Department's satisfaction, it might be advisable to send one of your officials to look the matter over.

Yours truly,

The Secretary
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

This my intention to organize a skating rink on the mission ground for our school boys. But I have not the required money for that purpose.

Would the Department help us with a grant of a hundred dollars ($100.00) or more?

If we could secure for them a skating rink, by keeping them away from places where they should not go, viz. poolroom, we could help them to live up a little better to the excellent education they receive at school, and so, the expenses so generously made by the Department for their formation, would not be partially lost.

Caughnawaga, March 5th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, dealing with a voucher submitted in favour of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada, Lachine, Que., for inter-school communications services at the local R.C Indian Day Schools, for final account with the Company.

In accordance with your letter on the matter, I communicated with the company in order to obtain another statement. They claim the enclosed statement to be in order with their records, and further stated that the misunderstanding might be due to the fact that the telephone service bills are payable in advance and that all the bills presented to this office, and transmitted to Ottawa, were paid at the end of the month, that is at the beginning of the next month, thus always leaving a month's arrear, hence the account of $5.66 for one month's service, plus $3.76 for the period between January 11th, and February 1st, when the phone was disconnected.

I beg to trust this information will be found satisfactory for the payment of this account.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Mines and Resources,

Caughnawaga, May 29th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I beg to refer to the last visit at Caughnawaga of Messrs. Phelan and Dudley and particularly to their visit at the Senior School where the matters of the painting of the outside woodwork and the repairing of the main stairs (at the front entrance) and also the refection of the six brick posts at the entrance of the yard. At that occasion I was instructed to ask one price for the painting and one price for the repairing of the brick work.

At the Senior School there are 59 windows, 5 ordinary doors and 3 large ones also a wooden cornice all around the building. The price obtained from a painter of the list, for one coat of paint to all the woodwork including the material, etc., is of $180.00. One coat would be given to the outside of the inside windows and the double windows would be painted on both sides, Putty would be applied where necessary. For a second coat, $125. more.

The iron stairs at the back, (fire escape) and all iron on the building would be brushed to remove the rust and painted for an additional sum of $40.00. For the iron fence at the yard entrance between the brick posts, the price would be of $10.00.

The price submitted for the refection of the 6 brick posts and the pulling of joints at the entrance of the school was of $75.00 including materials.

Both the painters and the bricklayer would be willing to do the work by the hour, if preferred by the Department.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

Ottawa, January 21, 1938.

Dear Mr. Allan:

I have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to payments for janitor services at the Caughnawaga R.C. Schools.

At one time we had three janitors for these schools, viz: Mr. Robert, Mr. Gatien and Mrs. Gatien. The latter did general cleaning under direction of the sisters and was paid at the rate of $300.00 a year. Some time ago it was found necessary to dispense with Mrs. Gatien's services and, instead of appointing anyone to succeed her, the Reverend Sister Superior was authorized to expend an amount of $150.00 a year, or $15.00 a month, for extra cleaning that is required. It has been the usual practice in the Caughnawaga R.C. Schools to do a great deal of cleaning during the summer months, in order to have these schools in good condition for re-opening after the holidays.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Caughnawaga, June 28th, 1938.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to refer to my letter dated March 11th, last, dealing with some repairs needed at the R.C. Senior School and more particularly to the roof of building which was leaking.

In this connection I wish to let you know that recently following a heavy rain, an additional part of the plaster ceiling fell due to the water coming from the roof.

It is feared that if the roof is not repaired soon, considerable damages will be done.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Can.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Phelan

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of the 26th ultimo, addressed to Mr. Chene, an engineer of this Service, with reference to some alterations required to the roof above the pupils' entrances at both ends of the Senior Day School at Caughnawaga, Quebec, which matter was brought to his attention by the Caretaker and the Indian Agent while visiting Caughnawaga last spring.

In this connection I am advised by the above mentioned officer that the work in question would consist in the continuation of the gable roof in order to eliminate the hips at both ends and prevent water or snow from any portion of the roof falling on the concrete entrances (landing and steps), which becomes dangerous when ice accumulates thereon during the cold seasons. The cost of the work above mentioned would amount to approximately $275.00, and the work, if authorized, could be carried out under the supervision of a competent carpenter with the help of local Indians during the summer holidays.

Encl.

I am enclosing herewith plans of this school building showing in red the changes recommended in its roof, which if allowed, would greatly improve the conditions of the pupils' entrances throughout the year.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Booth Bldg.,
OTTAWA.

T.S. Mills
Chief Engineer,

Per:
Ottawa, July 8, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to certain repairs required at the Senior School. Following receipt of your letter of March 11th, the matter of repairs was taken up with the Surveys and Engineering Branch, and they submitted an estimate of $275.00.

I do not know whether this amount was intended to cover the repairs to the roof which you mentioned. In their memorandum to us they specifically refer to their proposal to make alterations in the roof in order to improve conditions at the two entrances.

They are being advised today that, as far as the entrances are concerned, it is considered possibly a porch over each entrance would be sufficient and would involve very small expenditure. However, if their engineers consider that it is preferable to make alterations to the roof, we are giving them instructions to proceed.

If the repairs to the roof, mentioned in your letter, are different from the enlarging of the roof to prevent dripping, you may arrange for the necessary work, as I am under the impression, from your letter, that it will not involve any heavy expenditure. You may, also, arrange for the necessary plastering to replace what has fallen.

I understand that Mr. Chene is going to Caughnawaga in the near future to supervise the reconstruction of the Caughnawaga United Church School, and, no doubt, he will consult you regarding the repairs to the Senior School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Fr. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P. Q.
Ottawa, July 8, 1936.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Re: Caughnawaga Senior Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga Reserve, Quebec.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of Mr. Mills' memorandum of June 10th, with reference to alterations required at the Senior Day School on the Caughnawaga reserve.

I note from the memorandum that the estimated cost of these repairs will be $275.00. Before proceeding with the work, I would appreciate it if you would make certain that the expenditure of the amount mentioned above will remedy the condition about which complaints have been received.

It has been suggested that portable porches over each door would be sufficient. These could be erected at a very reasonable cost.

However, if you decide that it is preferable to carry out the work mentioned in Mr. Mills' memorandum and that this will permanently remedy the conditions, you may proceed with the work, and funds for the purpose will be forwarded to you upon receipt of your request.

Director.

With reference to the various matters which you discussed with Miss Walton and Mr. Phelan last Saturday morning, I beg to advise that according to information received by telephone from Mr. Stinson it will be quite in order for you to attend to any work or give our Agent any advice he may require during your stay in Caughnawaga. I understand that Mr. Phelan wrote to Mr. Wardle on Monday, the 25th, in regard to the toilets for the school and other matters you mentioned to him. Mr. Phelan's attention was drawn to the remarks you made by telephone to Miss Walton, and another memorandum was prepared and sent to Mr. Wardle stating that whatever was required to provide suitable toilet accommodation should be done, and that if an additional stairs was required this should be built. Mention was also made of the fact that it might be necessary to provide a well.

The Purchasing Agent was also advised by telephone that the foundation of the school would be completed by the end of this week, and that the materials had not yet arrived. Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Senior School,
Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, Que.

With further reference to the alterations proposed to the above building to prevent water or snow from falling on the entrance steps, I am quoting from a report on the subject just received from Engineer Chene at the site:

"With reference to the above matter I should advise that the installation of portable porches as suggested by Indian Affairs Branch would not be practical as such construction would be too heavy and offer many difficulties for their erection and removal each fall and spring seasons. There would be no convenient place for their storage and would entail quite an expense each year.

"After serious consideration I believe that the extension of the gable roof should be reconsidered if some alterations are to be undertaken to remedy the existing conditions. However, some permanent covering over the entrances, supported by steel brackets or posts, could be installed at an approximate cost of $200.00."

In view of Mr. Chene's report, it is considered that the erection of permanent coverings over the entrances, supported by steel brackets or posts, at an approximate cost of $200.00, would be satisfactory and advisable in this case.

I would be pleased to be advised whether this work may be undertaken and whether funds will be transferred to cover the expenditure required.

Respectfully submitted,

T.S. Mills

Mr. Wardle.

With reference to your memorandum of the 22nd ultimo, I quote herewith a report received from Mr. Chene on the heating systems, Kateri and Eastern Schools, Caughnawaga, P.Q.

"As requested I made an inspection of the heating systems of the above mentioned schools and beg to report as follows:-

(a) Kateri School (girls)

The system at that school is operated by means of a low pressure, cast-iron, sections, horizontal boiler, No. 946 as manufactured the Gurney Foundry of Toronto, which was found to be in a fairly good condition. The system is of sufficient capacity to heat the entire building satisfactorily but requires much attention and is expensive in fuel, (Stove coil).

In mild weather the fire in the boiler still continues to burn resulting in the consumption of an unnecessary quantity of fuel. These conditions could be remedied by the installation of an electric blower for the burning of buckwheat anthracite, which equipment would consist as follows:

One 1/3 H.P. electric motor and blower of required capacity with automatic control, thermostat, completed and installed..................$145.00.

Should there be funds available I would recommend that the alterations suggested herein be given favourable consideration.

It would appear that the above quoted report gives the information required by the Director of Indian Affairs as indicated in his memorandum to you of the 18th ultimo.

Caughnawaga, October 26th, 1938.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to refer to your letter of the 5th instant in connection with the recommendation made to the Department by the Surveys And Engineering Branch, for the installation of an electric motor and blower at the Kateri and Eastern Schools, and in reply to say that Mr. Chene, Engineer, states that the cost of heating would be reduced by one quarter.

The Engineer claims that the same quantity of coal would be required but as there is a difference of about $5.00 per ton between the prices of the coal presently used and the coal which would be required with a blower, the saving effected would soon pay for the installation suggested.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo in which you state that Mr. Chene considers a considerable saving could be effected by installing an electric motor and blower at the Kateri and Eastern Schools.

In addition to the cost of the blowers there would be the expense of the electricity for operating them. It is presumed that Mr. Chene has taken the latter expenditure into consideration.

About June 1, 1939, you should again bring this matter to our attention and a definite decision will be made at that time regarding the installation of blowers.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

F. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

January 20th, 1939.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Re - Alterations to Senior School,
Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, Que.

With reference to the coverings for the entrances to the above, which work was approved in your memorandum of September 16th last, I may say that this work has been carried out, with the exception of some painting which it is understood will be carried out without cost by the Caretaker of the school next Spring.

The expenditures on this work amounted to $247.64. This increase of $47.64 over the estimated cost of $200.00, which amount was authorized in your memorandum of October 24th last, is due to the necessity of carrying the concrete footings deeper than expected and also as it was not possible to obtain secondhand pipe for the posts as originally intended.

Mr. Chene advises that Mr. Phelan of the Indian Affairs Branch is aware of this increase in cost and is satisfied to provide the funds necessary to cover the additional cost. It is, therefore, recommended that the full cost of $247.64 be charged against funds which are available from the amount of $56,000 provided under Vote 168.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Re - Alterations to Senior School,
Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, Que.

With reference to the coverings for the entrances to the above, which work was approved in your memorandum of September 16th last, I may say that this work has been carried out, with the exception of some painting which it is understood will be carried out without cost by the Caretaker of the school next Spring.

The expenditures on this work amounted to $247.64. This increase of $47.64 over the estimated cost of $200.00, which amount was authorized in your memorandum of October 24th last, is due to the necessity of carrying the concrete footings deeper than expected and also as it was not possible to obtain secondhand pipe for the posts as originally intended.

Gaughnawaga, Que.,
June 6th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that the small shelter protecting the man hole cover of the Senior School sewage system, against ice and snow, was accidentally burnt together with the cover of the man hole which was made out of wood.

I would therefore kindly ask you to authorize its replacement and would suggest that the shelter be made out of stone in order that it be fireproof.

The materials required would be about four bags of cement at $0.70 per bag, one iron man hole cover, approximately $4.00, the size of which would be 2 by 2. As to labour it would take about 3 or 4 days, 8 hours per day, at 0.35¢ per hour. The stone would not cost anything as it is available in the School yard.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent
Ottawa, June 8, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant and to state that you are authorized to rebuild the small shelter protecting the manhole at the Senior School on the Caughnawaga reserve.

It is noted that you intend to rebuild the shelter with stone. It is scarcely necessary to add that Indian labour should be employed.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

F. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P. Q.
Dear Sir:-

I wish to bring to your attention the present state of the fence surrounding the yard of the Senior School which needs painting.

The wire fence is rusting and the posts and the wooden frame would be preserved if a coat of paint was applied. The paint would not cost anything as we have a sufficient quantity in stock for this work.

The cost of labour would amount to approximately $18.00 or two men at 30c an hour for about 30 hours each.

Kindly let me know if the Department would authorise this work.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Caughnawaga, Oct. 7th, 1939.

The Secretary:

Dear Sir:

I wish to transmit you herewith the resolutions passed by the local elected Council at their meeting for this month, held on the 3rd. instant.

Resolution No. 951.

With regard to that resolution I wish to inform that every winter a public rink is made by the Indians on the church ground. The children have certain days and hours to use it. The only time they are not allowed on the rink is when the senior hockey team is either practising or playing its regular games.

It is believed that the request of the Council for two skating rinks is untimely, especially under the present conditions, when money can be more usefully spent.

Fr. Brisebois,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

Please inform the Council that owing to present conditions the Department has no funds available for the purpose mentioned.

In reply I wish to give you the following informations:

As you are aware no accounts from this firm were submitted for November as they were awaiting for a decision as to the paying of the special war tax on electricity bills by the Indians.

In December the Company's meter reader computed his accounts on a one month's minimum basis instead of two months'. The second item on their December account for the Senior School shows, under rate 105, electric stove, 144 kilowatts for a total of $3.60, when it should have read $4.02, as the employee omitted to add the .21¢ monthly charge in that case, as can be seen in the back of the account.

For the same reason, on the Eastern school electricity account, he simply charged for one month's maximum of 1.4 Kw. a. at .33¢ per Kw. instead of for two months as should have been done, therefrom the arrears items of .42 and .41, which are a just claim.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer you to official letter of May 8, regarding the electric wiring system at the Caughnawaga Senior School.

No reply has yet been received. Please advise at once if you have obtained tenders, as requested. If so, these should be forwarded for our consideration. If you have no electrical firms on your list that could do this work, please let me know and the required names will be forwarded to you. Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to transmit you herewith prices obtained from four different firms in connection with the repairing of the electric wiring system of the Senior School of Caughnawaga.

The prices were obtained from Mr. Edwards Beaivais of Caughnawaga, Mr. Isadie Garand of Chateauguay, Mr. Lucien Favreau of Laprairie and the B.B. Electric, 5632 Park Avenue, Montreal. The four above named are of the approved list.

Although the tenders were requested to submit a price for the work that is absolutely necessary and a quotation on the whole work, Mr. Beaivais is the only one who made a price for part of the work. However his price for the entire job is higher than the three others.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, July 8th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing prices obtained from four different firms in connection with the repairs required to the electric wiring system at the Caughnawaga Senior School.

On reviewing your letter of May 6th it is noted that you stated that you were enclosing the report received from the Board of Examiners of Electricians for the Province of Quebec. However, this report does not appear to have been sent with your letter and, no doubt, it is still on your file. I would appreciate receiving it immediately as the prices quoted are much larger than we anticipated.

Do you think it necessary to do all the work on which the four firms have quoted? We did not have all these facts before us when preparing our Estimates for the current fiscal year and, consequently, you will realize that, due to the reduction in our Appropriation, it is practically impossible to consider making such a large expenditure without first having made arrangements for it.

An immediate reply to this letter, enclosing the report of the Board of Examiners of Electricians, would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

F. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.
Gaiginawaga, Que.,
July 10th, 1940.

Enclosure.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant dealing with the repairs to be made to the electric system at the Caughnawaga Senior School.

In reply I beg to enclose herewith the report of the Board of Examiners of Electricians of this Province, as requested.

Relative to the necessity of having all the work done I may say that according to the Examiner it should be done as the wiring system is considered unsafe. These defects were only discovered in the course of last Spring when considerable trouble was encountered quite frequently, which accounts for the fact that you could not be advised in time for the preparation of the Estimates for the current fiscal year.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

RE: Installation électrique à l'École Caughnawaga Senior School, Dept. Mines & Resources
RE: Electrical installation at Caughnawaga, Que.

L'installation électrique faite sur cette propriété a été inspectée et n'est pas conforme aux prescriptions de la loi et des règlements concernant les électriciens et les installations électriques; il est interdit de compléter l'ouvrage en voie d'exécution ou de le raccorder à une source de pouvoir ou d'y utiliser le courant électrique avant d'avoir corrigé les défectuosités signalées ci-après et d'avoir obtenu un certificat d'acceptation de l'installation.

The electrical installation in the above premises has been inspected and found to be in violation of the Law and Regulations concerning electricians and electrical installations and it is contrary thereto to cover up this work or connect same to any source of supply or use the current in connection therewith until the defects listed below have been remedied and a certificate of approval issued.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant dealing with the repairs to be made to the wiring system at the Caughnawaga R.C. Indian Day School.

In connection with the operation of a moving picture machine I wish to say that I am informed that if the proper wiring is installed for the lighting it will be sufficient to permit the operation of such a machine. No additional expenditure is involved. With regard to the moving picture machine I wish to inform that the sisters have from time to time borrowed one from the Loyola College, where they showed educational films to the pupils of their schools. This has happened three or four times in the past three years.

Relative to the electric iron I have to say that it is used in connection with handicraft work. The cost of the installation of proper size wiring for this particular work is of $10.00 or $12.00.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir;-

You will recall that in 1936 the fuel oil tank at the Senior School had to be replaced by a new one as it was corroded beyond repair. About 150 gallons of fuel oil had leaked into the ground.

The water of the well which was located near that tank became undrinkable as oil had seeped into the well. An Engineer was sent here and he instructed that the well should be pumped out from time to time stating that the oil would gradually be pumped and that the water would become normal.

At the present time there is only a slight taste of oil to the water and it is believed that very soon it will disappear.

As you are aware nobody resides at that School and besides the need of water for drinking purposes, the water from the existing well is quite suitable.

About 15 gallons of water are needed daily for the pupils and the domestic science class, which is supplied by the janitors every day from the Kateri School which is located about 200 feet from the Senior School.

However I have to inform that since the appointment of the new Superior several requests have been received in which she is insisting that a new well be bored, although it was explained that in view of the small quantity of water required for drinking purposes and the near possibility of utilizing the existing well as before, it would hardly be fair to incur the expenses of a new well, which would be considerable if an estimate is based on the cost of the drilling of the present one, which I understand cost over $800.00.

Will you

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
Will you kindly let me know if the Department will consider the drilling of a new well so that the new Superior be advised accordingly. At all events I would appreciate receiving a definite answer in order that this matter be closed.

Yours very truly

Indian Agent
Ottawa,
October 30, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant with reference to the well at the Caughnawaga Senior School.

It is noted that sufficient water for present requirements can be easily obtained from the Kateri School and that you expect that the water in the present well at the Senior School can soon be used. Under these circumstances the Department is not prepared to incur the expenditure that would be necessary to dig a new well.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum: The Director
Surveys and Engineering Branch.

Following a recent inspection of the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve by the Assistant Medical Officer of this department it was reported that the water from the well at the Day School had an oily taste, and was not being used for drinking or cooking purposes in the domestic science class.

The cause of the oil in the water is said to be due to the fact that about 150 gallons of oil leaked into the ground in 1936 when the tank containing the fuel oil for the school was found to be leaking, and had to be replaced.

No one resides in the school and the water is required for drinking purposes during school hours only. The matter was first reported to the department in October by the Indian Agent, who stated, however, that it was expected that the oil in the water would soon disappear and the well be used again. He was instructed to obtain water for the Day School from the Kateri School, where the well contained good water.

According to the Assistant Medical Officer's report, however, the drinking water is being drawn from the river. At the time that the artesian wells on the Caughnawaga Reserve were put down it was ascertained that the water from the river was not safe for drinking or domestic purposes. It is our intention to instruct the Indians Agent to see that the water used for drinking and in the domestic science class is taken from the well at the Kateri School, but I should like to know whether or not the well at the Day School is likely to improve or whether the oily substance in the water will continue for some time. If it was likely to disappear it would seem that it should have done so by now.

For your further information I would say that the tank containing the fuel oil which leaked into the ground was located close to the well in question.

Director.

Memorandum:

The Director.

Report of Inspection of the Oka,
Caughnawaga and
St. Regis Reserves.

I visited the vocational training rooms of the day school, including the class rooms. The children appeared clean and healthy. The Sister in charge complained of an oil taste to the water. It was necessary to draw the drinking water from the river. Apparently oil had seeped through the ground from the oil burner tank and contaminated the water. While the water was not fit for cooking and drinking, it was used for other purposes. The cost of digging a new well and the piping would be considerable, and it was thought that as later this well might improve it would not be advisable to recommend any changes.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant relative to the statement made to the Assistant Medical Officer of the Department that water from the river was being used at the Senior School.

In reply I wish to say that a mistake was evidently made by the one who made the statement as the water used at the School was never taken from the river but from the Kateri School well. The janitors who are taking the water daily to the School for drinking and domestic science purposes have not taken any from the river for use at the School.

The Sister Superior was advised of the contents of your letter.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water Supply, Caughnawaga Indian Reserve.

In reference to your memorandum of the 14th instant, with enclosure regarding traces of oil in the drinking water obtained from the well at the day school, we can see no reason why this condition should not disappear eventually, but constant pumping would no doubt accelerate the process.

If, as may be inferred from Dr. McGill's memorandum, the well is not being used, the removal of the oil from the immediate vicinity will be dependent solely on the movement of the ground water. We are unable to offer any estimate of the length of time it would take to clear up the situation either with or without pumping.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Chief Engineer.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Well at day school,
Caughnawaga Indian Reserve.

In reply to your memorandum of December 10th relative to the above, I am enclosing for your information a copy of a memorandum from Mr. Mills dated December 17th.

I may say that Mr. G.H. Ferguson, Chief, Public Health and Engineering Division, Department of Pensions and National Health, was consulted on this matter but he could not suggest any remedy other than pumping. It would appear, therefore, that frequent pumping is the only remedy and that considerable time may elapse before traces of oil can no longer be detected. It is suggested that the well should be pumped out completely as frequently as it fills.

Director.
